TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) for making the paper available in good time and for the opportunity to speak. We have just had some 35 minutes of another report from the Minister for Defence on the state of his equipment in the Defence Force. He comes in here periodically and gives us such reports. There is usually nothing new in them. One can only ask why he keeps on giving these reports and assume that in the event of a coup on the Government side of the House, which might happen very quickly, he is making his run, not for Prime Minister, I understand, but for Deputy.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing new in the statement today. What the Minister has done again has been to ignore the most pressing problem the defence forces of this country face-that is, the enormous and record wastage of personnel. The Minister talked proudly today about the savings he is to make. Will he give a commitment that the $200m he will be saving from other areas will go towards improving the conditions of service in the Defence Force? I bet that he will not. He has just read through 27 pages. Two pages make passing reference to people. Once again he has ignored the most important problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to get a whole speech from Ros Kelly on that.

—You are the Minister for Defence. It is your responsibility, as we have said in this House before. The Minister should not pass the buck to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who has no authority, has no money and cannot do the job, although not through want of trying. She does not have the authority to do it. The Minister comes into this House time and again and puts down a defence equipment paper, saying nothing about the people who are supposed to matter. They are looking to the Minister-70,000 of them out there-for some sort of leadership, and the Minister ignores them time and again. Until he takes some interest in those 70,000 men and women he will be hounded, not only in this House but outside it, in the media and by defence personnel. He is known as the Minister for defence equipment because he has no interest in the people who are supposed to matter. He comes in here saying that he is the Minister for Defence. He is the Minister for defence equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine the size of the problem once again. These are not my figures. They were provided by the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence the other day on wastage. We were forced to set out this joint parliamentary committee to take the matter out of the Minister's hands and put it in the hands of parliament so that it would get some attention. In 1983, 4,500 people left the Defence Force; by the end of last year, 1987, nearly 10,000 people had left the Defence Force-more than twice as many as five years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 6,800 in 1983-84. Where do you get your figures from?

—At the end of 1983 the figure was 4,500. On a 20-year average the number of pilots who have left the service is 47, on an annual basis. Last year, for the 12 months to the end of June, the Defence Force had lost 107 pilots. For the six months to the end of December 1987, 111 had submitted their resignations. It would appear that by the end of this financial year about 130 pilots, on the CDF's own figures, will have gone. Five ship's captains have departed. Two infantry battalion commanders have gone. Naval engineers and Royal Australian Army signallers have left in great numbers, according to the Minister's own Chief of the Defence Force.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unheard of-maybe not by the Minister but amongst professional service men and women-for anyone in command to give up his command. Perhaps such a person would retire after it, but I have never heard of anyone giving up a command. The most prized possession in the Defence Force is the command of a ship or an infantry battalion. This year, according to the CDF, the Defence Force has lost five ship's captains and two infantry battalion commanders. It is an absolute disgrace.

Let us not beat about the bush regarding the state of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). The Royal Australian Air Force, in its present form, is on the bones of its backside. There is one operational fighter squadron in Australia-75 Squadron in Darwin. It has 20 Mirages. On any one day 18 of them are probably on line, according to the figures--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all in Williamtown being trained to go on to the F18s.

—No. 75 Squadron at Darwin is the only operational fighter squadron in Australia. It has seven pilots and, on any one day, 18 aircraft. That is our front line operational fighter squadron. The Minister is taking an enormous risk in pulling them all out of our one operational fighter squadron to train them for the new squadrons. Let us consider the new F18 fighter squadrons being formed at Williamtown. Who reduced the establishment of pilots recently from 18 to 12? It was the Chief of the Air Staff. How many do they have out of that 12? They run at an average of eight or nine. So where are all these pilots who the Minister claims are being trained to go into 75 Squadron when it takes up the F18? It is a sleight of hand. The Minister is hoodwinking the people of Australia about the state of our defences. It is time that was exposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is presiding over the dismemberment of the defence forces of this country-and still he will not recognise it. Still he comes in here and talks about equipment, which has become an obsession with him. He refuses to take any notice of what is happening to the people out there. Is he going to leave it all to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, trying as she might be? She calls regular Press conferences and says, `I will look into it. I know that there is a problem. We are going to have a study. We are going to send Mrs Mayer'-her defence adviser-`to Townsville. She is going to solve the problems'. She is going to select half a dozen kids and put them in a school to see whether the constant disturbances of service life have any effect on their schooling. Do we need Mrs Mayer to do that? What a ridiculous approach to a problem. We are going to have more meetings, more reviews and more studies to look into it.

Let us deal with a couple of other excuses the Minister keeps trotting out. He says that the airlines are pinching all our pilots. We know that the pilots are going to the airlines. They have been going to the airlines for years. What is more, the airlines are not going to stop recruiting them. In fact, the problem will get worse. What is the Minister going to do about that? Is he going to look at some system of bonus payments, or is he going to stand around wringing his hands, watching the further dismemberment of the RAAF and blaming it on the airlines? Does he think they are going to change their recruiting policies? Does he think that if a good pilot fronts up to the airlines and says, `I am here in response to your advertisement', the airlines will say, `If you are from the RAAF we are not going to take you.'? Of course they are not. The Minister should wake up to himself.

He blames the Vietnam hump, whatever that means, for the enormous resignation rates. I presume that he means all the people who were in the Services during our involvement in Vietnam. Ninety-nine per cent of them have long gone. What do they have to do with current wastage rates? He blames the number of women in the Services for the high resignation rates. What a ridiculous excuse. The Minister is all talk and no action. The problems with the engineers and pilots will not go away. The Government must face the problem of what is happening in the Services and meet the market in some way, perhaps not by providing the full salary equivalent, but by creating an atmosphere and an interest for defence personnel, giving them productive, sensible lives, raising their conditions of service so that they are not second class citizens, making them feel as though they are doing a good job for this country. Otherwise the Government will see continued record level wastage rates. Look to the conditions of service.

The Minister talks about the Remuneration Tribunal. The Government opposed every single claim for a pay rise, except the last one, and then successfully delayed it for something like three months. The Government had deliberately delayed claims before the Tribunal for a flying allowance and other allowances. In desperation, people have said, quite rightly, that they are not interested. There is still a backlog of claims waiting to go to the Tribunal. Why does the Government not put some beef into it and get those claims heard and settled?

The Minister talks about housing initiatives. It is not enough. I acknowledge what the Government has done. Both sides of this House look to the Defence Force Housing Authority to see some improvement but it is still not enough. The Government still ignores the problem of single people. It will not pay them full removal expenses. I do not believe enough is being done about their barracks. The Government will not address the question of education allowance. At the last count, 87 people out of 70,000 received an education allowance to allow their children to attend a school. That is a ridiculous number. It is simply too difficult to qualify. The Government will not address the question of disturbance allowance. It costs people a great deal when they move-more than the $500 or whatever it is they get at the moment. The Government still has not addressed the questions raised by the Hamilton report on the Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses. Most of its recommendations have been ignored.

The Minister referred to how successful he has been in managing his equipment program. Only about a year ago he told us in this House how magnificent the defence forces were going to be because he had secured a real increase of 3 per cent for the next five years. That soon eroded to two, then to one, then this year to minus one. And still he says the plans he formulated based on a 3 per cent real increase have had no effect on his program. That is largely true because the Government has maintained its equipment program at the expense of 70,000 men and women. Apart from anything else, what does the Government think it costs to train 10,000 people a year? It is so proud of its recruiting figures; it should be ashamed of its retention figures. It is taking enormous amounts of money from other areas. It costs $2m to train a pilot by the time he gets to his first squadron. How many pilots will we lose this year? Perhaps the Minister can tell us. All the best guesses are that the figure will certainly be over 130. What are the training capabilities through the RAAF training system? About 70 a year. When is the Government going to address that problem?

I turn to some of the other matters that are canvassed in this paper. The Minister says how proud he is of the Government's efforts in northern surveillance. The northern surveillance of Australia is an absolute shambles. I quote from today's Australian an ex-Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal Evans. The report reads:
. . . Australia's coastal surveillance operation ``almost entirely useless'' . . . present surveillance was ineffective against anyone who did not want to be seen.

Air Marshal Evans said that overall the operation was `cosmetic'. He said that the coastline between Perth and Cairns had one radar at Darwin with a range of 30 kilometres. When asked a question about whether the north was wide open, he replied, `Absolutely'. That is what an ex-Chief of the Air Staff thinks of the Government's efforts in northern surveillance. As if that is not enough, Major-General Grey, a distinguished soldier and now the retired Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, said that the task given to the police-God knows why to the police-was an impossible task. He said the north was wide open and the situation was a shambles. Why does the Government not bite the bullet? Why does it not give this vital task to the defence forces and give them the control and co-ordination of our northern surveillance? Defence personnel are the people best equipped to do the job. They have the experience and the communications. They would not have to use very expensive military equipment on all these tasks; they could certainly use people such as those in Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd to do some of the job. The truth of the matter is that while the Minister comes into the chamber and says how proud he is, the situation is an absolute shambles, evidenced in particular by the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd fiasco earlier this year.

The Government has reduced the number of hours for long range maritime patrols from 1,200 to 700. It might like to explain how things have improved so much, when so many Indonesian boats are being taken almost daily, that it can afford to reduce the hours from 1,200 to 700. The reason is that the Government does not have the pilots to do the job. The Minister talks about the strike and interdiction capabilities. As far as I know, there is still no plan for refuelling of the F111 aircraft and as far as I know there is still no plan for airborne radar. If there are such plans, I would be very delighted to hear them. In the same breath as the Minister talked about interdiction he talked about our submarines. He and others keep going around South Australia saying we are going to cancel the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Aldred says that.

—Aldred does not speak for the Opposition. The Opposition has no intention of cancelling the submarine program. It was not without interest that I saw that the South Australian Government promised that the Green Fields site would be given priority. It now seems to be locked in some bitter industrial dispute which threatens the program. There are problems or potential problems with that program. The history of management of those projects over the last few years does not give us any cause for confidence. The ability of the Navy to manage that program with the enormous loss of engineers and to manage the frigate program at the same time is a worry to the Navy and to the Opposition. It seems likely that even if none of these problems appeared, with a project of that complexity there would be a time overrun. I ask the Minister: What is the sense of selling off Cockatoo Island at this stage with all the accumulated knowledge and expertise at that place, where people have refitted the present Oberon submarines, when Cockatoo Island may well have to be used for a further refit of the Oberons if the new submarine program runs on?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister talked about the strength of the Navy. The fact is that the Navy has been reduced to a brown water Navy. The thing that is exercising naval minds at the moment more than anything else is, with the decline in the capacity of the RAAF, how on earth will the RAAF perform the task that has been given to it of protecting the Navy as well. It has an impossible task, let alone providing any ground support for our ground forces.

The Minister mentioned the frigates. The selection procedure for the frigates is causing a great deal of concern as the Minister well knows. I hope that the system the Government has devised works but it has every chance of not working, and that is the concern. I would be interested to hear why the Government abandoned the more traditional methods of having people tendering for a particular project-in this case the frigate-and tried to force people into what might be some ill-sorted consortium. Another concern about the frigates is that in the end we will get shells of ships without proper armaments. The Minister also keeps claiming that we will have these eight new frigates. The fact is that they will barely replace ships in the Navy which are due for retirement at the moment.

I want to deal briefly with the two ocean navy concept. There is a sleight of hand trick perpetuated by the Government about our capacity in the west. The fact is that we have no ship lift capacity in the west at this stage to lift the FFGs or the DDGs. So there is no plan to send those ships to the west, because they would have to come back to the east if they were to be properly maintained. Of the whole surface fleet of the Navy, seven of the 12 ships are FFGs and DDGs. It is nonsense to talk about sending half the Navy to the west when seven out of 12 ships cannot proceed there. The Minister should come clean and tell us exactly what the Government proposes for the west. In addition, there is no fleet oiler to service and replenish those ships in the west. What does the Minister intend to do about that?

I turn to the matter of the PC9s. It is a surprise to me that the Minister in his statement today said that the PC9 `was acquired as an eventual replacement for the present CT4'. I have no doubt that that will surprise many people in the RAAF because they are working on the premise that what the Minister has done, against RAAF advice, is to introduce into a two-aircraft training system a third aircraft. Is it really proposed that this very powerful aircraft be used as an initial trainer? Is that really what the Minister is saying? By introducing a third aircraft into the system he is overloading an already overloaded system. The system will need more qualified flying instructors, and something like one-third of the qualified flying instructor positions around Australia are vacant at the moment. The Minister will complicate the eventual replacement of the CT4 and of the Aermacchi as a jet trainer. How is the introduction of the PC9 aircraft, so proudly decided upon by the Minister, going to fit into an already overloaded training system?

The Minister in his statement talks about the development of Tindal. The Opposition has no problem with Tindal as a base but we object to sending people there before it is completed. It is a fact that many people who are posted to Tindal have to go to Darwin because many of the facilities at Tindal are not ready. The Minister also talks about the 1st Division-six understrength battalions. Let us get that straight for a start. General Jeffrey, the commander of the 1st Division, believes that the division could exist in the field for only a few weeks. That is the commander's assessment, and at that it depends heavily on reserve units. The other day General Jeffrey, in response to a committee question, said that he believed he was 4,000 men short and that it was time the Government took some of the unemployed off the streets and put them in the Army. That is not a proposition with which I agree, but that is the sort of desperate comment that the commander of the 1st Division makes. The division is 4,000 men short and could sustain itself for only a few weeks. The Minister says that we have a stable trained force. If nearly 10,000 losses a year from a trained force of some 62,000 is a stable force it certainly gives a new meaning to the word.

On the question of defence property let me ask the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel: What is the Government's plan for the defence property around the Sydney foreshores that it is planning to sell to private developers? The local authorities and the last State government-the unlamented Unsworth Government, which now, thank God, is no more-wanted that land handed back to the Sydney Harbour National Park. What is the Government going to do about it? The Minister for Planning and Environment in the outgoing New South Wales Government, Mr Carr, was remarkably silent about this matter. He was the great environmentalist but he could not bring himself to defend that proposal. It will be an absolute tragedy if this Government goes ahead with its plan to flog off that land to some developer. It belongs to the Sydney Harbour National Park. I hope that now there has been a change of government the Federal Government will see some sense on the matter and renegotiate that with the new Government in New South Wales.

The Minister for Defence seems very proud, in his paper, that he has reduced the rank structure amongst the civilians at Russell. What about having a good look at it and reducing the total number of people in Russell and effecting some proper economies in that overgrown bureaucracy? That includes service personnel and it includes having a very good look at the rank structure of service personnel. There are far too many senior officers in the Australian Defence Force. Some of them have been put there to equate with bloated civilian positions, civilian ranks. So at the moment there has to be a brigadier to match so and so and there has to be a colonel to match so and so. The Army is pulling experienced, responsible commanders in from the field for a term in Canberra, as they should, and these people find that instead of being able, responsible commanders they are office boys around Russell. That is part of the reason why so many people in so-called responsible positions in Russell resign from the Services.

The statement refers to the defence contracting organisation. The decision to abandon the defence contracting organisation is wrong. The Department of Defence believes it is wrong, and it should be changed. By centralising it all the expertise is being taken out of the States and it is being given to the Services-not giving the services any more people-saying, `Get on with it'. It will be a disaster.

Finally, I turn to two broader and very important issues. I want to address the question of why this Government's foreign affairs and defence policies are on such divergent paths. The problem of intelligence gathering was mentioned today. If the Fiji coup and our knowledge of it is any indication of the intelligence gathering capability of this Government it stands condemned. We have the absolute neglect of the Pacific area by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden). The Foreign Minister has been wandering around Africa distributing money like a drunken sailor to the front line states, desperate as their plight is. Some $6m has been given to Mozambique without getting any guarantee of a fair trial for Mr Grey. At the same time aid is being cut to Papua New Guinea, which said today, `We will have to look towards Russia'.

The Government has ignored to a large extent the Pacific island states that are clamouring for some kind of leadership from Australia. The Government spends $58m on the total defence cooperation program with South East Asia and the Pacific island states, and it spends $100m on the front line states of Africa. There is something wrong with those priorities, and the problem is that the Foreign Minister is going down that track and the Defence Minister is going down another track. On Papua New Guinea there have been very serious differences between the Foreign Minister and the Defence Minister. On the question of arms sales the Minister for Defence has the hide to say that the Government is going to make an all out effort to sell arms. Who has been stopping the sale of Australian arms for the last five years? It is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

As far as the Pacific is concerned Australia has to give a real lead, and the Pacific Forum should be used for this purpose. It should be used to discuss regional defence matters, which Sir Julius Chan and Dr Brzezinski, a former national security adviser to Mr Carter, have called for. It is also of some interest that, according to today's newspaper, Dr Brzezinski at the Pacific Forum, which was conducted in Melbourne over the last couple of days, appeared to be slightly bemused `by the statements by the Defence Minister that there is very little threat from the Russians'. No-one is claiming that the Russians will come thundering across the hill tomorrow and overrun Australia, but why does the Government day after day have to apologise for Russian influence in this area? It is not in our interests to have the Russians day by day increasing their influence in the Pacific and South East Asia. It is reported that Dr Brzezinski:
. . . appeared to be slightly bemused by the statements by the Defence Minister, Mr Beazley, that the Soviets are not a military threat to Australia, but pose a political challenge.
Dr Brzezinski said:
It all depends what Mr Beazley means. After all, outside a war it is almost always a political challenge that has to be dealt with.

He has it absolutely right. Because we are not at war with a country does not mean we can ignore it and apologise for it. The largest Russian base outside the Warsaw Pact countries is in Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. It is not there by accident. The Minister for Defence says that it is there to defend the approaches to their homeland. Cam Ranh Bay defending the approaches to Russia? Why does the Government keep on with this apologist attitude towards Russian influence? The fact is that as long as we ignore the Pacific Island states the Russian influence will continue to grow. We have to use our influence in this area, perhaps through the South Pacific Forum. We on this side of the House suggest that that is the ideal way in which to do it. The $58m for the defence cooperation program is simply not enough. Sir Julius Chan, Dr Brzezinski and others are calling for leadership from Australia and we will be remiss not only in our duty but also in regard to our interests if we do not meet that challenge.

Getting back to defence issues; we should be using the skills and experience of our Defence Force personnel, who should go to these countries, if those countries so request, and give them some useful aid-certainly more than we are giving now. Engineers could be providing infrastructure in some of the Pacific Island states. We should be sending our Navy and Air Force officers to advise them on surveillance techniques and to assist them to manage their patrol boat programs. We have enormous skill and capacity in Australia but we have too many service men and women not being productively used. We should use that capacity; we should exert our influence by making use of those people, particularly in the Pacific Island states. It is in our interests to do so. Firstly, we have people of experience in these areas and, secondly, they would feel very much that they were doing a useful task for Australia.

The Government is failing its service men and women. It is not using its ADF skills to capacity; it is not giving defence personnel enough overseas experience. Our foreign affairs and defence policies are diverging. We lack the capacity to deploy quickly and we are not involved enough in the Pacific. On all these issues the Government has failed, but it has not failed on any of these issues as much as it has failed to look after the 70,000 men and women of the Australian Defence Force.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Kelly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate has agreed to the amendments made by the House to the Senate's amendments.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage done by failed Labor policies to the living standards of Australian families.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not surprisingly, a large number of post-mortems have been conducted throughout Australia as a consequence of the defeat of the Labor Government in New South Wales; the sweeping re-election of the Liberal Party Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson; the extraordinary, indeed unprecedented, swing against the Australian Labor Party in the two Western Australian by-elections; and the very impressive showing of the Liberal Party of Australia, despite all the Cain bluster about gun control, in the electorate of Kew in the centre of Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the themes that emerge from that analysis, of course, is living standards. There are many reasons why the Labor Party was devastated at the weekend and there will be many reasons why the Labor Party will be devastated at the time of the next Federal election. However, in raising my matter of public importance I want to focus my remarks upon the issue of living standards because living standards lie very much at the heart of the political and economic debate. Not only have they done so over the last five years, but they will continue to do so for the next couple of years.

There is undeniable evidence that over the last five years living standards in the Australian community have declined sharply. Average families have been squeezed in relative terms in a way that they have never been squeezed before. There are more people living below the poverty line than there were in March 1983. An average family needs a further $42 a week to restore its disposable income to what it was in March 1983. There has been an increased tax take over the last five years. Family allowances and dependent spouse rebates have fallen about 30 per cent in real terms. Average youth unemployment has increased sharply since March 1983. Interest rates, home loan repayments and housing waiting lists have also risen dramatically since March 1983.

The Government, in answering all of that, cannot deny that it has happened. It cannot deny the obvious. It has happened, and every family in Australia knows very well that there has been a dramatic fall in living standards over the last five years. To them the great myth of economic performance and achievement that we hear so frequently from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is a very sad, very sorry and very bad joke indeed. The answer of the Government is not to say, `Oh no, it hasn't happened-it is all a wicked Liberal lie, it is all a piece of coalition propaganda'; the Prime Minister and the Treasurer handle it in the classic way of confessing but trying to avoid blame. They say, `Yes, living standards have come down but, no, it is not our fault. It is the fault of the foreigners; it is the fault of the former Government. It is the fault of somebody else. Under no circumstances should the Australian public ever sheet home to us in the Australian Labor Party any blame at all for the fall in living standards over the last five years'.

It is as plain as a pikestaff to all but those who will not listen or learn that the Australian people no longer accept that Labor alibi. It is as plain as a pikestaff from Saturday's results, amongst the many messages that those results convey, that that alibi is no longer acceptable. It no longer has any currency at all, whether in the middle class swinging areas of Australia or in the traditional Labor Party heartland areas throughout this country. I put aside for one moment the reaction of those people to the extraordinary behaviour of the Prime Minister, particularly over the last few weeks. As a further illustration of his deteriorating behaviour, in Question Time today he sought on two occasions not to give a straight answer to two very straight questions. When finally asked another question that he could not avoid, he gave an answer that to many people on this side of the House was plainly less than convincing. The performance of the Prime Minister over the last few weeks, culminating as it did at Question Time today, is one of the reasons why hundreds of thousands of people have lost confidence, and will continue to lose confidence, in this Government.

I return to the question of the slump in living standards. It is undeniable that one of the reasons why living standards have fallen over the last five years is the adverse effect on the Australian economy of the downturn in commodity prices during that time. The Opposition has never at any stage over the last five years denied that fact. Never at any stage have we sought to argue that that is not an element. But what we do say, and what the Government will never accept and what increasingly the Australian people believe to be the case, is that the policies followed by this Government, particularly during the first 2 1/2 years of its five years in office, made a direct and major contribution to the decline in living standards that the Australian people are now experiencing. If the Government had not followed in its first two Budgets such an irresponsibly expansionist fiscal policy; if the Government had not in its first two Budgets run the two highest deficits in Australia's postwar history; if the Government in its first four Budgets had not sent taxation and spending to the highest levels since Federation; and if the Government had not, in 1983 and 1984, deliberately followed a policy that aggravated our then accumulating overseas debt problem, our living standards would never have fallen as far as they have, and the Australian community would not now face the bleak prospect of no appreciable improvement in those living standards in the immediately foreseeable future.

Nothing that the Treasurer, this man who this morning on the steps of Parliament House sought to evade any responsibility at all for the defeat of the Unsworth Government in New South Wales; this man who was once the President of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party; this man, whose basic constituency saw the most vicious and vitriolic anti-Labor swings anywhere in New South Wales, would still dissemble to the Australian public and say, `Look, chaps, we have got it right. It is just that you do not really understand how brilliant we have been'. A lot of people understand how brilliant he was as a political strategist! He might now seek to dump it all on Barrie Unsworth but almost two years ago he was anointing Barrie Unsworth. One of the most famous photographs in Australian political history is one of the Treasurer leading Stephen Loosley, Barrie Unsworth and Laurie Brereton out from under the stage. What can we say? Loosley's lost, Barrie's buried, but Brereton will be back. I do not think there is any doubt that all of the post-mortems that will go on about the New South Wales election will show that nobody did more to contribute to the installation of Unsworth as Premier of New South Wales than good old P. J. Keating. He was there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong! Wrong again!

—Oh, he says it is wrong. We are now going to have another little re-writing of the books, are we? I see, that is not P. J. Keating! It does not look like Rod Cavalier. Rod Cavalier would not mix with those right wing thugs, would he? He has got too much self-respect to mix with right wing thugs such as Stephen Loosley, Barrie Unsworth and Laurie Brereton. All I can say is that every Liberal in New South Wales relishes the prospect of Brereton being brought back. We cannot wait until Botany Brereton comes right back into prominence in the ranks of the Labor Party in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Let not the Treasurer imagine that my remarks are related merely to the political misfortune of the Labor Party in New South Wales. My remarks today go very much to the heart and to the honesty of the debate about the Australian economy over the last five years. In every sense of the word this Government has lived a lie about the Australian economy over the last five years. It has lived a lie that it inherited a deficit that never existed. It has lived a lie that for its first two years it followed policies that were appropriate to the state of the Australian economy. In the first two years that it was in government it did more to drive this country into debt than any government at any time over a two-year period since Federation.

When I ceased to be the Treasurer of this country, 26.5c in every export dollar that we earned was required to repay our overseas debt. This economic genius has taken that figure to a staggering level of 64c, and he has the nerve to stand up here day after day and say that people in Europe would be lighting candles in cathedrals in honour of his economic achievements. The Keating legacy has been to hang around our necks, the necks of our children and the necks of our grandchildren the most debt-ridden Australian nation that we have every experienced. In the course of that he has defiled his own alleged commitment to economic rationalism. He claims to be the great economic rationalist of the Labor Party.

Where is he in the privatisation debate? Why is he not out there in front, taking on the neanderthal thinkers in the Labor Party on the question of privatisation? DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Upgrade of Army living-in accommodation at various locations Australia-wide.

The proposed work now before the House was referred to the Public Works Committee on 9 December 1987. It is for the upgrading of 118 accommodation buildings in various locations throughout Australia to provide living-in accommodation as close as possible to the current defence standards as the existing buildings will permit. The scope of the work varies from building to building. Typically the upgrading of the barrack building will involve the conversion of existing four-person bedroom units to two single-person bedroom units; provision of common rooms; provision of change room facilities for personnel living out; upgrading of ablution facilities and internal engineering services; general repairs and refurbishment to the building fabric; and fire protection measures.

When I brought this proposal to the House for referral to the Public Works Committee, I advised that the project involved 124 buildings to provide 4,742 new bedrooms. The Committee's report is based on a revised Army requirement to upgrade 118 buildings to provide 4,568 bedrooms. The slight reductions reflect a reduced requirement for permament accommodation at Puckapunyal, partially offset by additional accommodation at Townsville. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $57.6m at November 1987 prices.

When the House referred this proposal to the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) requested that I ask the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to clarify where $50m will be spent this year on single living-in accommodation. The honourable member has misunderstood what the Minister said on 15 September in his Press release dealing with the 1987-88 defence budget. The reference to the $50m was for the project now before the House. But the amount concerns obligations and not cash allocations. There is unlikely to be any expenditure in 1987-88 on this project as, prior to inviting tenders, detailed documentation of the required work needs to be completed. Subject to parliamentary approval, it is intended that the initial tenders will be invited towards the end of this financial year, and the upgrading of the first buildings will be completed some five months later. Given the large number of buildings, it is necessary to stage the work, with the final building being upgraded in 1992-93. Design documentation and construction supervision will be carried out by my Department's construction group, with physical construction being contracted to private enterprise.
I thank the Public Works Committee for its prompt report and for the support it has given to the proposal, and commend the motion to the House.

It is clear that action needs to be taken to make the conditions for service personnel more attractive. Under this Government the attrition rate of Army personnel has been extraordinarily high. We on this side of the House are concerned about the reduction in the strength of the defence forces. The upgrading of Army living-in accommodation at various locations throughout Australia will assist in making service in the defence forces a little more attractive. As I understand it, a number of four-bedroom units will be refurbished as two-bedroom units. They will be upgraded and there will be common rooms and improved ablution facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the final number of single bedrooms is to be 4,568, I presume that we are losing the same number of beds, as four-bedroom units are becoming two-bedroom units. So we are losing a substantial number of beds. We agree that there is a need for an upgrading of the facilities. We wholeheartedly support the objective of the Government. However, given the substantial reduction in the number of beds, I wonder whether the Government has considered the longer term needs of the defence forces in regard to the supply of sufficient and appropriate accommodation.

I would be interested if the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), who is at the table, or the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), could provide me with an answer. I have heard around the traps that the Australian Army is to request some 220 new single soldier's accommodation at Enoggera, Queensland, which request will go to the Government for the financial year 1988-89. So, as I have said, we are seeing a substantial reduction in the total number of beds, with a decrease of around 4,500.

The Government has a duty to the House to explain its goal in regard to the provision of appropriate accommodation for the defence forces. This proposal certainly will meet the needs of some existing personnel and provide improved accommodation, which is needed. But, I repeat: as part of the planning of government we ought to be looking further ahead than today. We need to know what are the longer term needs of the defence forces and to provide for them. I have no doubt that many of the problems the defence forces currently face under this Government are a result of the Government's lack of planning. The forces are losing servicemen. Service morale is obviously affected by the accommodation and services that are provided. So, whilst the Opposition supports this motion to improve the accommodation of our service personnel, we ask the Government to provide to the Parliament and to the people information on the longer term planning the Government should be undertaking for our very deserving Defence Force personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most appropriate that I respond after the presentation by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) of that report on defence accommodation. SPEECH.PARA: I should like to explain once again for members of the Opposition the break-up of the Defence portfolio between the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and me. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) seems basically unable to understand that in the break-up of responsibility it is I who have the paramount responsibility for personnel issues and it is therefore I who will be addressing them in my comments today. The Government's position is a combination of the position of the Minister for Defence and mine.

The honourable member for McPherson is totally inconsistent on the personnel issue. From his 30-minute address today we have learned that his solution is only one: to pay more money. He revealed today that his solution to any problem in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) we might have is to meet the market; that is, whatever a Defence Force person could earn in the private sector, it is up to the Government, to quote the honourable member, `to meet the market'. I will deal later with the analysis of the people we are losing from the Defence Force. They are those people who are very attractive to the private sector-the pilots, the engineers, the computer experts and those involved in project management. The honourable member does not tell us how much his solution of meeting the market would cost. He does not tell us where the money would come from.

I wonder whether he has consulted the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) about his new proposal. The Leader of the Opposition, on the other hand, says that public sector spending must be cut back even further than this Government is doing it. If he would `meet the market', as he says, what equipment program would the Opposition drop? I challenge the honourable member and the Opposition to tell us about that. Does he believe we should drop the over-the- horizon radar, the Geraldton project, the electronic support system for the P3C Orion or the 16 Sea Hawks? Does he believe we should drop the increased capability of the submarines or the new submarine project? Does he believe we should drop the mapping and charting program or the Anzac patrol frigate, the mine hunters, Nulka, the move to the north, the two-ocean navy strategy, the FA18 purchasing program, the upgrading of the F111 avionics or the 67 PC9 pilot training aircraft, the northern airfield structure at Tindal or the 39 Black Hawk helicopters? Where does he say the money is coming from to pay what the market demands for these personnel? Does he want it to come out of our housing program for marrieds and singles?

Besides wanting to pay all this money to meet the market, he does not want any money from asset sales: we should not get our hands dirty with any asset sales. He found a new role for the Defence Force. He suggested defence personnel be taken away from proper military training and used for northern surveillance. What equipment does he want to use? Does he want to use the F111s or FA18s for northern surveillance? The reality is that if we use the equipment we have now it would have to be taken away from proper military training. If, on the other hand, we took on that role and we bought new equipment, where would the money come from? What would we not purchase? Would we then decide to scrap our FA18 program? The policy does not make sense. It is easy to see why the honourable member for McPherson stays in the shadow Ministry rather than the shadow Cabinet. Maybe if he got into the shadow Cabinet he would get some idea of the overall economic direction that the Opposition is supposed to be taking. His proposal just does not add up.

As we listened to his rhetoric I thought of the Opposition's history of handling of defence. The gap between its rhetoric, what it has promised and what it has delivered is enormous. Its emphasis in this debate has swung back and forward between equipment and personnel. The Opposition's defence policy in government is chaotic and is in incredible contrast to the sensible, stable, well balanced policy that we have presented in the defence White Paper. It harks back to the October 1976 White Paper when Defence Minister Killen said that the then Government would restrict expenditure on manpower and operation and concentrate on capital equipment. But at no stage were his financial commitments ever honoured. In the first Budget following that defence White Paper cuts were announced and after five years-the period the Killen White Paper was supposed to cover-the equipment program was behind what it was at the time of the announcement.

Then suddenly the then Government saw the light. There was another change of direction because in 1980 there was the Afghanistan conflict. Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser said that World War III was going to occur so defence spending had to go up-seven per cent. But by this time Defence personnel were almost mutinous, and it takes a lot to get people in the Australian Defence Force to that stage. So Prime Minister Fraser was forced to bring down an increase in salaries for defence personnel. But the problem was that the salary increase had to be absorbed in the defence budget. On 29 April 1982 the then Defence Minister, Jim Killen, came into this House with the greatest backdown in political history. He stated that his Government could not meet the capital procurement programs: it just did not have the money. The Government had to pay the defence forces more because it had frozen their salaries for so long but many capital equipment programs had to be cut down. There were no additional Fremantle class patrol boats, the Canberra aircraft was paid off and defence personnel were told to use commercial charters. That is the sort of chaos that this Government was confronted with. There was a big stress on capital procurement and then the Government realised it had to deal with the personnel and found that there was no money left for further capital procurement.

When the Opposition was in government it never thought about the financial priorities. As a result, its policies were totally inconsistent. It could not deliver on any front. None of its White Paper promises at all could be met. In contrast, the defence White Paper brought down a year ago by the Minister for Defence is on track. It is a balance between personnel and equipment and it is based on strategic defence requirements plus realistic economic conditions.

The first issue I would like to deal with in some detail is that of the numbers of people leaving, and I want to put that in perspective. It is a fact that a total of 8,919 people, or 12.8 per cent, left the Defence Force last year-not 10,000, as the honourable member for McPherson said. It is also a fact that at present separations are given as a single percentage figure, which is not specific enough to pinpoint where our problems lie in retaining experienced personnel in the Defence Force. In fact, it works to mask the areas where we are experiencing problems. It is important for honourable members to be aware that the overall separation statistics include personnel who temporarily separate from the ADF, such as those who go on maternity leave and personnel leaving for more than three weeks without pay. The statistics also include cadet trainee category. Some cadets and trainees find during their training that service life is not for them and they go. They leave the Defence Force at about twice the average rate, yet they are included in the statistics. The enhanced role of the reserves has also caused an apparent increase in the separation rates. After a period on full time duty reservists returning to their units count in our separation figures.

The two main categories of separations are those who are eligible for pensions and those who leave before they are pension eligible. It is this category, the 5.9 per cent of service men and women who left the service in 1986-87 before their 20 years were up, which is the critical component in our separation profile. This compares with a 10-year average of 5.1 per cent. So there is an increase but it is about 0.8 per cent in that key category. This means that in 1986-87, 491 ADF personnel over and above the 10-year average left the service before their 20 years were up. That is the extent of the problem.

The honourable member for McPherson referred to five ships captains and to two battalion commanders. In fact, there were five ships captains and two unit commanders, and they all left after their 20 years were up. If the honourable member wants to change that policy and encourage them to stay longer he should perhaps suggest that we change the pension system. There is no doubt that there are problem areas. These include Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) pilots and people in the computer field, but the people in these areas have always been very attractive to the private sector. It is not just a problem now; it is a problem that has existed for a very long time. A report in 1982 highlighted the fact that people in these sorts of categories that were attractive to the private sector were leaving. It was a problem in 1982; it will probably always be a problem in the Defence Force unless we can offer them salaries equal to those in the private sector, and I believe we cannot. We obviously have to keep their salaries in line with trends in the community and we are doing that. We are doing that through the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, and recently we have seen a 4 per cent second tier wage increase that flowed on immediately to the ADF. The Government has supported that. We have had increases in the service allowance of 22 per cent, in the field allowance, in the submarine, seagoing and hard lying allowances, and we also have an increase under way in the flying allowance. These are areas in which we are making some input.

I do not have sufficient time to go into all the details of improvements in Defence Force personnel issues but I will list just some of them because we should take them on later in the debate. The Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff, a recommendation of the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses, is providing support to families. Education is also an issue where action was needed and I delivered immediately in that area. We now have a special tuition allowance for children from the last two years of primary school right through to high school. Added to that we have a new system for trying to get some uniformity in our otherwise diverse State education systems and I am piloting a scheme throughout Australia. This is not talk; this is action. These are key areas for Defence Force personnel. We are also spending $750m on housing, and that is an area where we will see considerable improvements, not just in the provision of capital but also in repairs and maintenance.

This Government gives high importance and emphasis to defence personnel. This is a balanced White Paper. We believe that our most valuable assets and our most vital resources are Defence Force personnel and their families. That is why there is now a Minister specifically directed to look after Defence Force personnel issues. I am very committed to that. I see myself very much as a spokesman for Defence Force members and their families. We have made significant improvements in this area and we will continue to do so in a sensible way, fitting in with our defence White Paper, with procurement policy and with the economic directions of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone in the precincts of Parliament House at lunchtime today would have been aware of the considerable and noisy Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) activity outside. One wondered whether these activities were some novel form of intimidatory tactics adopted by the Government in a last desperate bid to silence the Opposition's response to the statement made this afternoon by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Perhaps it was the precursor to a coup attempt by frustrated Australian Labor Party factional back bench members anxious to maintain their seats at the next election, or Barrie Unsworth beating a fast retreat from the debacle that was last Saturday's New South Wales election. Perhaps it was the last of our remaining Hornet pilots rushing to the Qantas or Cathay Pacific recruiting offices. In fact, it was none of these options. I am reliably informed that the display was an initiative of the Minister for Defence to draw attention to his statement on the implementation of the defence White Paper. It is no wonder that service personnel continue to display their confidence in the Minister by leaving in droves.

SPEECH.PARA: Having listened to the Minister's statement this afternoon one wonders why he should be so enthusiastic about highlighting what could generously be described as 27 double-spaced pages of misleading waffle and meaningless rhetoric, exceeded only by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) a moment ago. If this is the best the Government can offer we are in diabolical strife. In fact, as far as our defence position is concerned, `diabolical strife' is a mild term. After all, our defence policy is, or should be, all about defending Australia. The basic question the Minister should be addressing is: `Can our armed forces adequately defend us?'. This question was posed by the well respected and authoritative defence writer Peter Young in an article which appeared late last year in the Australian. The answer, he contended, must be a definite no, at least not for the foreseeable future. In this article, Peter Young referred to some of the major factors influencing the present critical situation facing our defence forces and their effect on our defence capability. In the context of the Minister's statement today, some of Young's comments are most relevant and provide an excellent summary of existing problems for which, apparently, this Government is unwilling or unable to find adequate and appropriate solutions. He continued:

As a result the emphasis has shifted to the development of an operational deployment force capable of meeting this lower end of the threat, and which in turn would be backed up by the deployment of heavier forces and increased logistic support as the situation developed.
This is all very well in theory-especially when based on what Defence minister Beazley always qualified as `credible' threats.
Others, however, see them as carefully contrived scenarios designed to fit our limited capabilities in much the same manner that the Dibb report was written around the existing hardware.
Peter Young continued:
But the hard facts are that we don't even have a full division, since each of its three brigades can field only two battalions.

This first-line force of only six under-strength rifle battalions and scaled-down supporting arms and services is demonstrably incapable of defending vital installations, let alone meeting any major threat.
These are the words-and warnings-of one of Australia's most highly regarded defence commentators and analysts.

TALK.START.PARA: —By you.
—I notice that the Minister refers to him when and as often as it suits her. His conclusion bears repeating:

SPEECH.PARA: This first-line force is demonstrably incapable of defending vital installations, let alone meeting any major threat.

The Opposition has continually highlighted and warned both the Government and the community generally about the obvious and ongoing deficiencies which have led to this appalling and alarming decline in Australia's defence capability-most of them attributable to past and present financial constraints and the continuing policy of this Government to pretend that the very real threats facing Australia, and the enormous problems now facing our defence planners and forces do not just exist, or, if they do, will apparently solve themselves. The worst, the most critical, problem is the enormous loss of trained personnel from all sections of the defence forces. Thirty-six per cent of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel left the Services in the three-year period to June 1987, and the projected loss rate in all areas of defence administration for this year is in the vicinity of 16,000. This is a deplorable and potentially disastrous state of affairs. Again I refer to the words of Peter Young:
The defence forces themselves are doing the best with what is given them, but it is obviously not enough. They are now being asked to make bricks without straw.

As a result, while a two-battalion response force might be able to deal with a single minor incursion, our defence forces are neither structured nor supported to defend the nation in the face of anything bigger than a strictly limited low-level threat.

The effects of the current wastage crisis were examined during Senate Estimates committee deliberations on 22 October last year. In responding to a question from Senator David MacGibbon regarding the impact of the present high Royal Australian Air Force pilot resignation rates on the FA18 program, Air Vice-Marshal R. W. Bradford, Deputy Chief of the Air Staff, said:

Obviously if we are losing pilots, the losses are occurring amongst our more experienced pilots. Whilst our overall numbers are still not very far down on what we would wish, our numbers of experienced pilots are considerably down.
In response to a further question, the Air Vice-Marshal continued:
We are suffering more because of a loss of experienced pilots-those who have been in the service, in the main, between, say, six and 16 years. They are the ones who are leaving.
Senator MacGibbon also asked about the current position with respect to qualified flying instructors:
Do you have enough? Have you had resignations from experienced pilots?
Air Vice-Marshal Bradford replied:
We do not have enough QFIs at the moment. Our loss of pilots has included a large number of qualified flying instructors. Our ability to make up the QFI shortfall is limited.

The House should note that further crippling losses of experienced pilots and qualified flying instructors continue to the present day and show no signs of abating. Senator MacGibbon asked Bradford why the resignation rate had gone up. Bradford offered the opinion:
Fundamentally it is a quality of life problem.

This should be of serious concern to the Minister. He went on to mention factors such as better pay and conditions offered outside the Services; increased mobility in terms of career aspirations; more pressure in regard to children's education; more pressure on wives to work; and the effect of constant postings-on both spouses and children. The Minister acknowledges:
The Opposition said a lot about our defence personnel policies . . .

He goes on to accuse us of not offering solutions to what he describes as `the undoubted difficulties the ADF faces in keeping highly skilled people'. Of course we have offered solutions-but the Minister has conveniently chosen to ignore them. When the problems are as obvious as they are, the solutions are also obvious: better conditions of employment, better living conditions, better recompense, and better recognition for the responsibilities and challenges undertaken by the members of our armed forces which will in turn lead to a sense of purpose and achievement; in other words-and this is something that the Minister has not even remotely mentioned to date-job satisfaction.

Despite the Minister's glib assurances that everything is under control, it is obvious that the personnel wastage situation is still out of control-and there is little indication or prospect that the position will be rectified in the near future. It must be remembered that the strength of our defence forces lies in personnel-not equipment. Equipment is necessary to maximise that strength. There is an old and well-known military adage:
Mongols without horses are still a force to be reckoned with, but horses without riders are nothing.

There are many obvious deficiencies in the Minister's statement. I have chosen to concentrate on that area which has always been of primary concern to me-the people who are our defence forces. I remind the Minister that new planes, new submarines, new minesweepers and expanded Jindalee over the horizon radar stations are useless if they cannot be manned by trained personnel. It is fatuous to discuss the relocation of significant elements of the defence forces to our northern regions if there are not enough forces to relocate. Equipment can be purchased more readily and quickly-and sometimes more cheaply-than the personnel needed to operate them can be recruited and trained.

Whilst this Government continues to ignore-or at best pays lip-service to-the Defence Force wastage crisis we are facing, the Minister can deliver statements to this House till the cows come home but they will be, as his statement today has been, empty boasts with potentially disastrous implications for the future security of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the statement made by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) I will not indulge myself or waste the time of the House by commenting on the very fatuous and distinctly uninformed remarks of Opposition speakers so far-the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), neither of whom addressed the key issues of substance that were raised in the Minister's statement. The statement details progress on the implementation of the proposals in the Government's White Paper on defence. It underlines this Government's commitment to both a coherent defence strategy and an enhanced defence capacity that its policy of self-reliance in defence requires. I remind the House, as the Minister for Defence said in the statement which he tabled on 19 March 1987, that `this strategy dictates that we develop an Australian Defence Force (ADF) capable of meeting any hostile force within our area of direct military interest, with successive layers of forces capable of detecting, identifying and engaging any hostile approach'. As the Minister said then in his statement, `this strategy is, in the broadest political sense, defensive'. It is to be emphasised that a comprehensive defence in-depth strategy requires military superiority in the sea-air gap to the north and across northern Australia. `Defence in-depth' means that an opponent would have to defeat a layer of deployed assets through and to our north.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister pointed out in his statement of March 1987, there would be three layers to this approach. The first layer comprises high level and comprehensive intelligence about military developments in our region, and a variety of surveillance capabilities to detect and track hostile intruders in our maritime and air approaches. The second layer is a naval-air capability to destroy enemy forces in our approaches and to protect local points and shipping lanes. It means, for higher levels of conflict, having forces able to strike at an adversary's base and being able to interdict his lines of supply. The third layer comprises a flexible ground force with air and naval support to react to any enemy incursion on our territory and be able to protect dispersed population centres and civil and military infrastructure.

The establishment of a Northern Command based at Darwin is of particular relevance to this structured defence. Hitherto, the ADF has had a joint control structure in Darwin, without a `command' hierarchy of the type that will now be in place. The new structure should not detract from the integrity of the existing joint service arrangement. The Minister, in his statement to the House today, emphasised that the new structure will be a `true joint force headquarters'.

Paul Dibb in his Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, in referring to the need for the Government to consider regional command and central arrangements and the expansion of defence assets in Northern Australia, said of the establishment of a Northern Command joint Force headquarters:

The headquarters might be on an experimental basis at first, and developed further as experience indicated. The establishment would recognise the importance of credible northern contingencies, and would allow a smoother and more effective transition from peace to hostilities.

Importantly, the establishment of Norcom will provide the capacity for a number of additional functions to be undertaken in the Top End. The new command structure will be in a position to work on operational matters, to have greater involvement in the planning and coordination role in training and the carrying out of major exercises and be responsible for the trialling of new techniques and pieces of equipment.

An aspect of the function of the ADF in northern Australia which Norcom in conjunction with the Defence Command in Canberra would be involved in, would be the ongoing development of a doctrine for northern defence. This will inevitably require some assessment of what force would, in the case of an emergency, be required to protect key installations such as the Tindal and Darwin airfields, the naval base at Coonawarra and the various communications bases in Darwin and, down the track, including Jindalee and other critical national installations as well as major towns. In my view, such an assessment would highlight the need for additional land forces to be based in the Top End and for the deployment at some future time of ADF personnel in important towns in the Top End.

An important aspect of these new command arrangements is the relationship that is built up between civilian infrastructure that may be involved in any conflict, especially low level conflict, where for example Australian territory may have been breached by a small party of insurgents. Defence is everyone's responsibility and requires the closest of cooperation between civil and defence authorities. Confident effective working relationships between defence personnel and civil authorities, especially police and emergency services, is of paramount importance if our defence strategies are to be effective. Currently the joint forces in the Top End enjoy a close relationship not only with the police and emergency services but also with the political and administrative hierarchies and the civilian community generally. The establishment of the Northern Command will provide for a higher level of involvement on a continuous basis between the ADF and civilian authorities in the Top End.

With the deployment of the FA18 squadron at Tindal, the basing of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment in Darwin by 1992, and the important future deployment of a battalion or brigade to Darwin at some further time down the track, there will of course be major social and economic impacts, not only in terms of the host community but also in terms of the defence personnel who are transferred on a long term basis to what is a remote area, away from family and other support mechanisms that they have in other parts of Australia.

It is important that defence and civil planners alike remain cognisant of and attuned to the problems that may arise with the deployment of relatively large numbers of defence personnel into areas of comparatively small populations, such as Katherine and, to a lesser extent, Darwin. The lessening of any negative impacts will occur only with continued close cooperation between the ADF and civilian authorities and communities. In my view, the Australian Armed Forces Federation is, from an ADF viewpoint, very important in this regard, as are the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses and the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff. It is of the utmost importance that in areas such as Katherine, that will feel the significant impact of the deployment of large numbers of defence personnel, the local community is safeguarded and, most importantly, that Aboriginal people are not further marginalised in their own country.

In economic terms, the injection of funds to acquire assets such as Tindal and to upgrade and consolidate existing ADF infrastructure in Darwin in particular has provided a great deal of stimulus to the Northern Territory economy. To date, in the Tindal project some 379 houses have been approved for construction. In the next stage, stage 2 of the project, a further 20 houses will be built. This will mean that a total of 399 houses will have been approved for construction by the end of this year. The total project cost is $230m, of which $175m has either been spent or already been committed for spending. Defence expenditure on capital equipment is $75m, of which $24.5m has been spent on housing.

Before construction of the Tindal air base began the population of Katherine was 4,000. By the end of 1988 it is expected to have doubled to 8,000. This emphasises the impact of the Tindal development on the Katherine community. Prior to the expansion of Tindal there were only two banks in Katherine, and now there are four. There is a new Woolworths Ltd store which employs 110 people. Seven hundred to 800 people have been employed in the construction phase of the Tindal base, and there will be 70 permanent civilian jobs when the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base becomes operational. Expenditure on an annual basis in Katherine will be around $10m to $20m. The arrival of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment in the Top End will be at a total cost of $79m, and the construction of 175 married quarters will cost some $19m. This all emphasises the importance of capital expenditure from the Commonwealth, in terms of the deployment of defence personnel in northern Australia, to the Northern Territory economy.

Capital expenditure aside, as I have illustrated, the deployment of large numbers of defence personnel with their families will have obvious long term multiplier effects on the Northern Territory economy and will contribute directly to much needed long term job creation within the general community. There are important and tangible spin-offs to northern Australia which have resulted and will continue to result from the build-up in the defence presence in the Top End. The level of defence expenditure underscores the primary role of the government sector as a basic stimulus to economic growth in the Territory. The Government is conscious of the potential of these economic benefits to be derived from the deployment of personnel to the Top End and the acquisition of capital assets to the Territory economy, and it has provided special briefings on the proposals for the Top End to business communities and Northern Territory Government representatives, as well as to unionists.

There is little doubt that there are significant opportunities for private enterprise in the Top End in servicing the requirements of the expanding defence force in the region. The challenge for the business community is to be competitive, to demonstrate that it has the skill and expertise to provide the services that will inevitably be required. Unfortunately, difficulties have arisen at Tindal which have delayed the deployment of some personnel to the base. Such delays may require the Government to adopt a more rigorous approach in the oversighting of contracts. A by-product of the ongoing presence and exercising of the ADF in northern Australia is that other direct benefits accrue to the civilian population, particularly in the area of search and rescue.

I was recently a witness to a joint search and rescue operation off the Cocos Islands in the Indian Ocean, which islands, as you will know, Mr Deputy Speaker, are part of the electorate of the Northern Territory. This operation involved two P3 Orions, one from the United States Navy based at Diego Garcia, one from the RAAF's 92 Wing under the command of Flight Lieutenant Terry MacKinnon, based at Edinburgh in South Australia, one civil aviation Gulf Stream based in Perth and one Canair F27. The cooperation and professionalism shown by all involved, including the flight service personnel under the officer-in-charge, Jim Downey, and the administration at Cocos Islands under the Acting Administrator and Official Secretary, Mike Jopling, were extremely impressive and highly commendable.

This is but one example, of course. The reconnaissance role of the Air Force and the work of the naval patrol boats is crucial in protecting us from incursions along our northern coastline from unwanted visitors who may have as their purpose the poaching of Australian fish or the landing of illegal immigrants. There are obvious direct and indirect benefits in these activities, not the least of which is the protection of livestock and native plant and animal species against exotic diseases that may be imported as a result of such unwanted landings.

As the third layer of the defence strategy requires a flexible ground force, it is important, to carry out appropriate training and exercises, that the ADF has access to land across the Top End. In this respect it is significant that Norforce, an Army component of the land based operations of the ADF in the Top End, has in general very good relationships with landholders in the Top End, particularly with Aboriginal people. I wish now to draw the attention of honourable members to a comment of a former commanding officer of Norforce, Lieutenant-Colonel Neil Weekes, that appeared in the Sunday Territorian on 2 February 1986:
The traditional owners and the Land Councils have been extremely co-operative with Norforce and have never refused entry of a patrol onto Aboriginal land.
That's more than can be said about a number of private property owners who on occasions have refused us permission to conduct exercises on their land.

That last comment should be of special interest to members of the Opposition. Two weeks prior to this statement being made, the then Premier of Queensland had claimed publicly that land rights were a threat to the defence of the north. Such was his sophistry. The fostering of such a positive relationship, where the ADF is mindful of and has respect and regard for the unique relationship that Aboriginal people have with the land, is an important element in guaranteeing the success of the flexible response that the Government's defence strategy demands.

I emphasise that the concept of self-reliance demands that the Australian community accepts the responsibility for maintaining a level of credible defence that would deter any would-be aggressor within our region. There are other defence strategies that could be applied but they would require an even greater level of commitment from the Australian population generally or would place an intolerable burden on others to protect our interests. Self-reliance provides us with the capacity to become more independent and less reliant on others. I support the statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the House on this important defence statement I should like to remind the honourable member for Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) that it was a previous coalition government and a former Leader of the National Party in particular that took on a driving role with regard to the Tindal development, that magnificent project at Katherine in the Northern Territory.
