SPEECH.PARA: This progress report was delivered by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is obviously enjoying the power that has been conferred on him to list items of business now that he has become the Leader of the House. Not long ago, last month, a further defence paper on self-reliance, cooperation and Australia's regional defence policy was delivered. I welcome both debates. For too long the House of Representatives has not considered the fundamental issues of defence. If it be a bonus conferred on this House that the Minister for Defence now occupies the position of Leader of the House, so be it. I disagree, however, with many aspects of the statements made by both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who have contributed to this debate this afternoon.

Too often we take defence for granted. In my role as the Opposition spokesperson on veterans' affairs, I have moved around Australia and have met with veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel, and serving personnel. In doing so I have encountered many concerns about Australia's defence preparedness and about the nation's commitment to its defence. Concern is expressed also about the range of decisions that have been taken by the Government, particularly the 2 per cent cutback in the defence force retirement benefits (DFRB) pension payments and the chopping and changing of the defence service home loan scheme. I wish to refer at some length to both those issues, because I want to focus on defence personnel, which was to the forefront of the statement of the Minister for Defence. At page 21 of his statement the Minister said:
The Government recognised in the White Paper that the highly skilled and dedicated members of the Defence Force are our most valuable defence resource.
With that statement I agree. The statement continued:
The Opposition said a lot about our defence personnel policies, but they have offered no solutions to the undoubted difficulties the ADF faces in keeping highly-skilled people.

I disagree with that second contention. Through the shadow Minister for Defence the Opposition has offered a comprehensive approach to a defence policy. At the time of the July Federal elections, as part of the formal policy documents of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, and more recently during debates on defence in this Parliament, the Opposition has taken a strong stand in relation to the conditions of service pertaining to defence personnel.

The Opposition recognises that morale in the defence forces is, as I have said on previous occasions, very much on a knife edge. I do not refer in this sense to unit morale. Unit morale, by and large, is worked on in a comprehensive manner by individual Defence Force commanders at all levels. They work very hard to ensure that whatever difficulties face particular units, a strong spirit exists within that unit; for example, in the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment, the submarine HMAS Onslow, and 75 Squadron Royal Australian Air Force in Darwin-that is, if sufficient pilots were available to enable that squadron to enjoy a fighting unit morale. I have been supplied with information which reveals that the number of pilots in that squadron is down to single figures. There are insufficient pilots-in fact, only sufficient to fly fewer than half the number of aircraft available to our one and only operational squadron in that forward northern region. What a disgrace! There are only seven pilots at this time equipped and ready to operate in the defence of this nation, no matter what type of warfare or conflict might suddenly arise. It can no longer be said about planet Earth that one can predict confidently that Australia will not become involved in conflict for ever more. That would be a head in the sand, unrealistic approach.

Unit morale is maintained through great efforts of skills of man management, but it is not helped by the examples set by the Government. It is not helped by the knowledge that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), for his part, with regard to defence forces' roles seems to spend a great deal of his time on golf courses by day and on occasion a good deal of his time playing backgammon by night, running between the two and leaving very little time to run the country in the process. That is the perception. His Sunday morning confession to the media in the aftermath of the New South Wales State election result does little to assuage the feeling of the community at large that it has a Prime Minister besotted by the golf ball and by blackjack cards. Running the country is a hobby, an interest, to which he devotes himself in between his games of golf and his visits to casinos.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cheap.

—I am told by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, who is at the table, that that is a cheap shot. I tell honourable members that I mix around the streets of Albury and Deniliquin in my electorate and I attend farming meetings throughout the rural part of Australia and visit factory floors, and that is what they are saying at the grassroots level. So it is not a cheap shot. It is a shot reflecting the feeling at the grassroots level. They have had enough of a Prime Minister who spends a Friday getting a hole in one. I do not for one moment begrudge him a degree of hobby activity but I believe that he should keep it in perspective. He should be reminded that he is Prime Minister of this country with enormous commitments associated with that office and that he is responsible for his image. The public at large today and the Army, Navy and Air Force personnel who would dearly like to be able to go and play golf and backgammon commensurate with their particular station in life are not able to do so because of the Defence Force service conditions that the Hawke Labor Government has brought forward under its five years in office.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it very clear that I am only referring to the Prime Minister in passing in the context of this defence debate. But it is relevant because these are signals, perceptions, which the Government is sending to our sailors, airmen and Army personnel. They are not happy and they have a right not to be happy. Let us look at what the Government has done to their Defence Force retirement benefits. No fair dinkum shop steward-if there are any left amongst all the dark-suited, cigar-smoking members of the Federal Labor back bench-would accept what the Government did to the DFRB pension payments. The Government breached a contract with the workers-in this case the personnel of our armed forces. On 10 October 1986, as part of the then Budget strategy, the Government applied a 2 per cent cut. Since then the Government has stated quite clearly that the defence forces and other Commonwealth superannuation pensions will not be discounted in perpetuity and that pension benefits will be restored as soon as economic circumstances permit. But nothing has yet happened. I understand that the matter has gone back to Caucus for review, but a number of communications and submissions have been made by veterans organisations such as the Returned Services League, the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association and many other veterans organisations seeking a restoration of that 2 per cent cut. It would be a tremendous signal to send to the armed forces personnel of this country that the in perpetuity aspect, the compounding aspect, of that 2 per cent cut will be rectified in the mini-Budget or Budget later this year, as has been promised by the Government. I say to the members of the armed forces and the ex-service personnel in particular, `Don't hold your breath, because there are no guarantees that this particular constituency will be accorded the same sort of priority that the Government accords to various other sectors of the community which, in my book, should enjoy a whole lot less priority'.

I believe that the Government is responsible for the morale of individuals in our service being on a knife edge. This has exacerbated the resignation rate. The other key area is that of defence service home loans which was chopped and changed throughout the last quarter of last year to an extraordinary degree. Initially, we had a new scheme announced with the cessation of all $25,000 loans and instead a $10,000 grant. A week later we had the restoration of the $25,000 loans and a narrow window whereby a person could still apply for the $10,000 grant, one-off tax free mechanism. Then suddenly in December there was another chopping and changing with the Government abolishing the $10,000 grant, reducing the maximum term from 32 years to 25 years and, to be fair, admitting that it brought in portability of new loans but, by and large, leaving a very unhappy Defence Force with regard to both the 2 per cent DFRB compounding cutback and the defence service home loans scheme. There still has been no real progress in the privatisation of that scheme, which has been promised so often since May 1985. The Government has lost all credibility on that privatisation.

The situation with our defence forces personnel is crucial. For many it has reached a crisis stage and they have made a decision to resign, which has decimated the ranks of experienced personnel in our armed forces, as the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), has pointed out very capably. There is another reason why this situation has prevailed. I refer back to the debates on the Veterans' Entitlements Act in April 1986 when the Government said that it was going to bring forward a military compensation scheme for serving personnel to replace the use of the Repatriation Act, now the Veterans' Entitlements Act, for those serving personnel. Now, some two years later, we have had neither sight nor sound of a military compensation scheme. There has not been a signal from the Government that it is genuine in proceeding with a military compensation scheme. I remind the House that it was only the action of the Liberal and National parties that ensured that enlisting personnel remained at least under repatriation cover during this interim period, which has now extended to two years, before the introduction of a military compensation scheme.

So there are many reasons why our veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel feel very strongly about defence, entitlements and the downgrading of defence service conditions and have taken the final step of proffering their resignations where they are members of the Navy, Army and Air Force. It is not too late for the Government to fight back. Today it put on an equipment display on the lawns in front of Parliament House. It is typical of the Government's efficiency. We were notified of the display fairly late this morning and had no warning of it. Perhaps Government members had earlier notification. It was a pity because it was a magnificent display, yet the numbers attending were not all that large. In the circumstances of a parliamentary sitting day I am sure a lot more members on both sides of the House would have gone across to that display had they received earlier notification of it. I did feel for those pilots who buzzed Canberra, Parliament House and the Parliamentary Triangle today. My gosh, they must have been tempted to come down a few extra feet and really shake the windows of this Parliament to get their message across. The Minister and Government members are out of touch with the defence constituency. They are not communicating with any degree of accuracy with the key people who make up that constituency. It is about time that they got back in touch for the sake of running the defences of this country for the few short months that they remain on the treasury bench in this House until the next Federal election, whenever it occurs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve months ago the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) came before this Parliament and put forward a statement on defence policy which the Minister said `set the course for a decade or more of development of self-reliance in the defence and security of Australia'. It is appropriate, 12 months later, that we, as a parliament, review and debate the progress of implementation of that strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with great interest to the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who rightly commented that it was the Minister for Defence who initiated debate on the Defence White Paper and on the Government's progress in implementing action on that strategy. What a tragedy it is for this Parliament that we do not have an opposition that is prepared to take up defence issues and bring them before the Parliament. What a strange irony it is that it is the Government which initiates debate and at least gives the opportunity for the Opposition to raise points of policy. Perhaps the honourable member for Farrer would do well to speak to the shadow Minister, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who has not addressed one question without notice to the Minister for Defence since the last Federal election. It is not my approach to make personal attacks on people, as honourable members will know, but I must say that the honourable member for McPherson is not doing a job in this Parliament for defence personnel. That, of course, is reflected by his Leader's refusal to permit him to join the shadow Cabinet. How the Liberal and National parties have changed from years gone by. In those days the Opposition-the then Government-did accord some priority to defence and to the issues of defence personnel and their families. But now those issues are not voiced by anyone in the shadow Cabinet and the shadow Minister has not asked one question of the Minister since the last election.

I am very pleased to be able to participate in this debate because it provides an opportunity to review progress. When the Minister for Defence put forward his statement to the Parliament 12 months ago it was greeted with universal acclaim by defence commentators. The prominent newspapers of this country referred to the Minister's statement as a bold defence plan and recorded the fact that there was virtually no substantive criticism. Twelve months down the track, despite the enormous difficulties we face as a nation, we have lived up to our commitments in that initial statement by the Government.

I want to say something briefly, by way of introduction, about the role of defence in the future of our country. I believe that a prerequisite for national security, independence and the peaceful development of Australia is the capacity for self-defence. Our defence policy must ensure our territorial security and freedom to develop as an independent nation. This requires an independent capacity to defend our own territory, our offshore resources and our maritime approaches. The conviction of the Australian Labor Party is to base our defence and foreign policy on the belief that war can and will be averted. We believe that Australia has a part to play in its prevention. Nevertheless, a strong defence capability must be maintained and be effective to demonstrate beyond all doubt that Australia intends to defend itself and its vital interests. There is no inconsistency whatsoever in promoting a forthright view, promoting peace and disarmament throughout the world and, at the same time, promoting an independent and viable Australian defence force.

There is one omission from the Minister's White Paper and his statement to the House 12 months ago. One matter the Minister did not mention-I think it is important to mention it in this debate-is that Australia did then and continues to renounce the option of nuclear weapons for Australia. This Parliament, by virtue of the passage of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Act, became the first sovereign country in the world to renounce, by way of domestic legislation, the option of nuclear weapons. That law, which passed through both Houses of the Australian Parliament, rules out the option of nuclear weapons for the defence of Australia. It rules out their permanent stationing on Australian shores. It is a matter of profound regret that the Opposition was not prepared to support that important statement of principle which sends a signal to the world.

I have spoken in broad terms of how I see the development of the Australian Defence Force and how that relates to my personal philosophy and my commitment to the principles of the Australian Labor Party for an independent and peaceful future for Australia. I return to the subject of the Opposition, before I relate a number of matters regarding the Government's achievements in its defence policy, particularly the achievements it has secured for defence personnel and their families. I have told the House that the Opposition has not asked one question of the Minister for Defence. That amounts to an abdication by the shadow Minister and it is probably one of the reasons why he is excluded from the shadow cabinet. I ask the shadow Minister, on behalf of the Australian defence forces and their families: What is the Opposition's defence policy? Is there a document? Is there a policy statement? Is there a speech which contains some record of the Opposition's views? The answer is that there is no policy. We have heard no statement from the Opposition about what it would do if it were ever to form a government. We have heard horrendous stories about the cuts that would be made in the Budget of the Commonwealth of Australia affecting a whole range of services across Commonwealth outlays. The cuts proposed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) would strike at the very heart of the Government's defence strategy and would amount to a sabotage of all that this Government is trying to achieve. I challenge the Opposition to tell us where the cuts would be made.

The Minister for Defence dealt comprehensively with the broad strategic questions and issues of equipment purchase and industry policy. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) raised issues concerning the programs and policies of this Government put in place to benefit service personnel and their families. My contribution as the member for Hughes is to expand on the contribution made by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I have a special interest in this area as a member representing an electorate covering Holsworthy, Moorebank, Hammondville, and other important areas of my electorate where defence personnel and their families live. I represent the naval estates of Heathcote and East Hills. I am very much committed to ensuring that at the local level those communities get the best possible deal from this Government.

I believe that all honourable members who represent service communities, especially those members on the Government side, have to take a national approach to this question. That is why the Minister who is at the table, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), and other members of our Party established the Government members defence force action committee. It is a group of back bench members committed to intervene and defend the rights of service personnel and their families.

There have been criticisms by one person, who has had some publicity as a journalist, about the integrity of our committee. When the crunch came, and there was some threat to the defence service homes loan scheme, the Government members committee, comprising Labor Party members from throughout Australia, stood shoulder to shoulder with service personnel and their families to ensure the preservation of that scheme. I believe that our integrity is beyond doubt.

For the first time in the history of this Parliament, a group of back bench members are prepared to take a united stand and be outspoken to protect the interests of service personnel and their families. The major reforms which have been initiated by this government during its term of office and which are directly related to the Government's defence strategy are the report of the Hamilton Review of the Effect of Service Life on Spouses and the initiatives flowing from it; the establishment of the Defence Service Homes Corporation; the establishment of the Defence Forces Remuneration Tribunal; initiatives to assist with the education of service children; the establishment of the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff; improvements in posting policy; support for the establishment of the Armed Forces Federation of Australia; establishment of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses; and improvements in the lot of single members of the Australian Defence Force, as referred to in one respect in the report concerning improvements in living-in accommodation tabled immediately before this debate.

I could speak in some detail about each of those important initiatives but my time is limited in this debate. However, I want to set the scene for the strategy that lies behind the Government's initiatives. One of the centrepieces of this Government's strategy for its third term of office is its national social justice strategy, which is a unanimous tenet of Australian Labor Party policy, adopted at its last National Conference. That strategy supports a number of key initiatives, including the promotion of access to economic resources and power, the proposal to protect and expand the rights of individuals, the important principle of ensuring greater equity of access to goods and services, and the expansion of opportunities for participation in decisions affecting the everyday lives of Australians.

They are noble goals; they are statements of high principle. We on this side of the chamber make no apology for being idealists. Our mission, our goal, is to expand the horizons of Australians and to deliver to them our broad social justice strategy. I raise that matter in the course of this debate to remind the House that before this Government was elected to office service personnel and their families were the forgotten people. An hour ago in this House I spoke about soldiers literally living in World War II slum huts in my electorate, and adjacent to it, when I was first elected to Parliament in 1984. That situation was a disgrace and a blot on this Parliament; but, more than that, there were no opportunities for participation, or for lobbying by service spouses and their families. There was no Armed Forces Federation. The Government has set in place not simply token reforms but institutional reforms, structural reforms, that cannot be taken away by a future government. I truly believe that the sum total of these initiatives is to change fundamentally for all time the conditions of service personnel and their families. I compliment the Minister on initiating this debate and I thank the House for the opportunity to participate in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Government's isolationist defence philosophy is further advanced by the progress report of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Yet again, the guise of self-reliance is very thin indeed. Regrettably, this Minister has made Australia a laughing-stock. His recent statement that the Soviet Union is not a military threat to Australia, but is merely a political challenge, has been greeted with total disbelief among our allies. It is a quite incredible statement. As far as I am concerned, the Minister's political problems, or challenges as he prefers to call them, will lead to war if they go unresolved. History is full of examples of governments which, to unite their people in a common cause when confronted by major domestic problems, have externalised those problems by going to war. Indonesia did so in the 1960s when it sought confrontation with Malaya; more recently, Argentina did likewise when it invaded the Falkland Islands.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's statement about the Soviet threat being a political challenge demonstrates a basic lack of understanding not only of history but of Australia's defence needs. The fact is that this Government's isolationist philosophy is causing our allies and an increasing number of Australians a great deal of concern. At present Australia does not have the capacity to meet either its own defence needs or its obligations to the Western alliance. Let me give a simple example. In 1951 Australia accepted allied responsibility for protection of merchant shipping over vast areas of the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean when it signed the Radford-Collins Naval Control of Shipping Agreement. Under that agreement, Australia's area of responsibility stretches from just east of the Seychelles to beyond Tuvalu. That commitment is still binding on Australia. However, the defence policies of this Government have clearly put our commitment beyond the capabilities of the Royal Australian Navy.

In his progress report the Minister has again concentrated on Australia's area of responsibility in the Pacific Ocean. Once more he has evaded comment on the precarious situation now confronting us on our western border. That situation, of course, is the build-up by India of a navy capable of dominating the entire Indian Ocean region, and particularly our vital western approaches. Our northern border region does not get the attention it merits, and our southern border is totally ignored.

The Pacific area has long been neglected by this Government. Only in recent times has the Government attempted to rectify this particular problem. This Government's neglect of the Pacific region was highlighted as recently as yesterday by the Deputy Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Sir Julius Chan, who spoke of his country's expanding educational ties with the Soviet Union as being a result of what he called-and I quote-the `closed door policy' by Australia. In other words, because Australia has neglected the region, the countries which form the region have had to look elsewhere. Inevitably, it has been the Soviet Union that has been only too willing to provide assistance to them.

Yesterday, Dr Zbigniew Brzezinski, National Security Adviser to the President of the United States of America from 1977 to 1981, referred to the massive increase in the Soviet Pacific fleet and the attempts by the Soviet Union to translate military power into political power. We are all very aware of the growing political influence of the Soviet Union in our Pacific region. However, it is little wonder that this has occurred, given our minuscule political, diplomatic and military presence in the region.

Our western border, formed by the Indian Ocean, clearly does not appear on any map the Minister may possess. For many months now I have been promoting discussion on the massive Indian naval build-up occurring in the Indian Ocean, discussions in which the Minister has refused to become involved in the hope of keeping Australians ignorant and therefore quiet. The only public comment he made was on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program on 24 February when he added a whole new dimension to Australian innocence by saying:
India is not a country that has been hostile to us. There is nothing in Indian policy which is hostile to us.

That was an extraordinary response to a substantial shift in the strategic balance in one of our major oceans. Neville Chamberlain could not have said it better. It also begs the question in my earlier remarks on the Minister's comments on political challenges. Were Indonesia and Argentina ever hostile to, or did they promote policies hostile to, Malaya and the United Kingdom before provoking the respective wars which took place? The answer in both cases is clearly no.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —To take up where I left off before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I reiterate that the Minister for Defence shows a demonstrable lack of understanding of strategic defence. During question time at yesterday's conference on Soviet ambitions in the Pacific, Dr Brzezinski referred to the possibility that internal domestic problems in India could lead to a break-up of the union, a possibility now being seriously considered as a result of the seemingly insurmountable ethnic domestic problems facing India. Should this begin to eventuate it is not unreasonable to suggest that the Indian Government, following the lessons of history, will consider uniting its people by externalising its problems-that is, provoke a confrontation.

SPEECH.PARA: With such a large and powerful blue water navy and India's ability to project her military power through her forward bases and aircraft carrier forces, Australia, because of its weak defences, could well be a logical choice to confront. We would be easy prey for an Indian military adventure directed against the Cocos (Keeling) Islands or Christmas Island. The Indian build-up should have begun ringing alarm bells in the Defence Minister's office a long time ago. It did not.

Recently there was considerable media coverage surrounding the Soviet delivery to India of a Charlie class nuclear submarine, presumably for use as a training vessel by the Indian Navy. Yet still there was no comment from the Minister on this further tipping of the balance of power against Australia. Since India acquired this somewhat outdated and noisy nuclear submarine I have ascertained that she is to acquire six more. Until now it was thought that these would be of the relatively old Sierra class. However, I am now informed that the six submarines are to be of the advanced Victor III hunter-killer class, capable of launching the Soviet SS-N-7 underwater launched anti-ship missile, which can carry a nuclear warhead.

Whilst the Soviets may not supply the nuclear warheads, India's domestic nuclear weapons program is believed to be close to producing the nuclear warheads that would be needed. Again during question time at yesterday's Institute of Public Affairs defence conference in Melbourne, Mr James Webb, who recently resigned as United States Secretary of the Navy, referred to the Indian expansion as obviously having major implications for Australia. I am, therefore, not alone in my concern.

It was somewhat heartening to read in the Minister's statement that elements of the defence forces are being permanently deployed in defence of our northern borders. This is particularly timely, given the now changing political scene in Indonesia which is of some concern. The latently anti-Australian General Benny Murdani was problem enough when he was the commander of Indonesia's armed forces. Now that he is Defence Minister the problems can only get worse. Furthermore, the outward aggressiveness of General Murdani will no longer be restrained by the calming hand of Dr Mochtar, the Foreign Minister, who has consistently been favourably disposed toward Australia, because President Suharto has seen fit not to reappoint Dr Mochtar-a very sad fact for the region and for Australia, and, I might add, for Indonesia. The Indonesians look like becoming the second regional power to acquire nuclear submarines. At present they are seriously considering acquiring the French Rubis class nuclear hunter-killer submarine, an action that will further tip the strategic balance against Australia.

I turn now to Australia's fourth border region to which the Minister made no reference whatsoever. Our southern border fronts on to the Great Southern Ocean, which in turn forms a border for the great land mass of Antarctica. Our southern border is important, particularly because of one key method of analysis the Soviets use to interpret the global geo-strategic axis. Essentially to facilitate their geo-strategic military planning, the Soviets have broken the world into two halves and have moved the polar axis in both. The northern half of the globe, with the pole centred on Moscow, is regarded primarily as an area requiring domination by ground forces. The southern half of the globe, with the pole centred on Sydney, in New South Wales, is regarded as an area requiring domination by maritime forces. It can, therefore, be appreciated that the Southern Ocean is integral to the Soviet's quest to increase their military and political influence in our region.

Politically, the Soviets have already demonstrated that they regard themselves as having an interest in Antarctica. Indeed, they have recently established a base on Australian Antarctic Territory without notifying Australia-a serious contravention of the spirit of the Antarctic Treaty. As well as pressure from the Soviets, there is continuing pressure through the United Nations from the countries of the non-aligned movement, which are seeking to internationalise Antarctica and dislodge Australia and other Western powers. It can thus be seen that in the future our southern border region can expect to see much more activity from numerous countries, all of which aim to weaken Australia's territorial claims on Antarctica. As far as is known, the Minister for Defence has not undertaken any strategic planning to counter these pressures.

Yet again, the Minister's presentation lacks any strategic perspective or perception of the major problems increasingly confronting us on our four major oceanic borders. TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill is to amend three sections of the Trade Practices Act: section 53, section 65u and the section relating to the ability of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to authorise prosecutions without depending upon the authorisation of the Minister. It is our assessment that this addition is probably in the best overall interests of that section. As a non-lawyer, I am fascinated to hear judges make comments on value, as indeed I am to hear all lawyers make comments about value. But this addition is quite consistent with the words used and, although I must rely on the judgment of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) in this matter, I am quite sure it represents the best possible position. As a consequence, the Opposition supports the amendment proposed by the Government to section 53.

I turn to the amendment to section 65u. The original intent of this section was to give the States an appropriate amount of time to introduce uniform legislation. The Government appears to have abandoned hope that such legislation may occur. As you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as well as other honourable members would be aware, consumer affairs Ministers meet to make determinations about particular products, and they have requested the States to bring forward mirror legislation. Therefore the States should be granted an extension of time to implement the decision taken, presumably, by the Standing Committee of Ministers of Consumer Affairs. Some States have not met their responsibilities as laid down by the Standing Committee. As a matter of fact, only Queensland and Western Australia have been able to put in place legislation in response to the Standing Committee. The States have powers under their food Acts, as they were introduced under a procedure endorsed, presumably, by the consumer affairs Ministers. The fact that the other States have not met the timetable does not mean and ought not to mean that the Federal body can come in under this legislation and pre-empt any action by the States to enact such legislation.

The Opposition's proposed amendment would ensure that the States were given adequate time-we are proposing two years-to enact their legislation in preference to another grab for power, and the centralisation of power, by the Federal Government. This in itself might not seem particularly significant but it underscores the Australian Labor Party's push for central power. Although only a small area, it is another area that exemplifies what the coalition views as an unnecessary intrusion into State powers in Australia. Because of that we do not believe that we should authorise a permanent extension of Federal power in relation to this matter. The two-year extension of time we propose is necessary in order to ensure that the States can introduce the necessary legislation. Mr Deputy Speaker, coming from New South Wales, you would readily understand that State governments may have some other matters on their minds.

TALK.START.PARA: -As the honourable member would know, State governments all around Australia, even in Queensland, have other things on their minds.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other aspects of this matter which we really ought to talk about, including the whole area of consumerism and the Liberal Party's approach to it. The Liberal Party of Australia and the coalition generally are very committed to consumerism. The Liberal Party believes that there is no inherent conflict of interest between the consumer and the provider in a private enterprise system. The public interest lies in democratic institutions and in direct consumer sovereignty. The great difference between the coalition and the Labor Party is in our approach to consumer affairs. Our approach is to free up public enterprises, to reduce waste and public expenditure and to reduce regulation, which regulation leads to increases in costs. The Labor Party's approach is to set up committees, councils and advisory groups and then to put consumer representatives on all these bodies. That creates more red tape and wastes more public money, and these groups are removed further from the real problem. Our commitment stems from a belief that the marketplace, on the whole, can provide the best for consumers. There is a very real need to protect the health, wealth and welfare of Australians as far as possible.

Part V of the Trade Practices Act, which relates to consumer protection, has been widely supported by business at large. Regulation has its place, but it must be scrutinised closely to ensure that it meets two criteria: firstly, that there is a clear deficiency in the market resulting in a need for regulation; and, secondly, that regulation, if put in place, must have a fair chance of correcting that deficiency without causing unnecessary disruption to the market. Part V of the Act largely meets these criteria but each and every regulation must undergo this sort of examination. This conflicts quite strongly with remarks made by members of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO). Recently at a symposium entitled `Business Regulation, When Does the Consumer Profit?' AFCO said:
Consumers want at least the current level of protection afforded by regulation.
The rhetoric of de-regulation goes too far . . .
The outcome of the regulation debate will significantly shape the legal and social environment of the Australian economy in the years to come.

It was the Liberal-National Party Government that put in place the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, which today commands a great deal of influence and advises the Ministers with responsibility for consumer affairs. Its membership comprises four consumers, five business people and six various other representatives. We should not delude ourselves by thinking that the Trade Practices Act is the one and only form of consumer protection in Australia. Reform in the wider macro-economic environment, the lifting of tariff protections, the reviewing of merger and takeover activity, and the removal of burdensome government taxes and changes would all provide great relief to consumer.

Privatisation is another area where the benefits which would accrue to consumers would be very great. The inefficiencies of many of our public enterprises, and the inability of the Australian Labor Party to address these inefficiencies, are inflicting more pain upon Australian consumers than the whole of the business community could ever inflict. I draw attention here to a couple of complaints made in 1986 about Telecom Australia, one of the great institutions about which the Labor Party said, `We must review it', and then today said, `We must not touch it because it is one of those bodies that give a public service'. But it gives a greater public service to members of a particular trade union which has great influence within the Australian Labor Party.

In 1986 complaints made against Telecom won it the brickbat award. That is quite something. The North Sydney rugby league team could not even win that. Oral complaints to the Ombudsman in Canberra about Telecom rose by 10 per cent in 1982-83, by a further 9 per cent in 1983-84, by a further 9.7 per cent in 1984-85, by a further 9 per cent in 1985-86 and by a further 12 per cent in 1986-87. Written complaints rose by 24 per cent, 17 per cent, 14 per cent, 13 per cent and 17 per cent, respectively. The reason for this rise is that a public instrumentality such as Telecom has no consumer body which looks at its affairs. It is self-regulatory. If people complain to Telecom, it will give them its answer because it is not answerable to anybody. Good old Telecom! It regulates itself. It is a wholly government owned and operated public monopoly. If there are any complaints it says, `We will give you an answer. That does not mean to say we will give you satisfaction'. As a consequence, the people associated with the services of Telecom, who are not all wrong, sometimes have a lot to bear.

Recently we have heard a lot of debate about this. But we have not heard much debate about the interests of the consumer or the person who pays for the use of Telecom's facilities. We have heard a lot about who should own it, who should pay for it, who should raise the money for it, and the working conditions of Telecom's employees. But we have not heard a lot about the consumer or the user of Telecom. That is an area in which the coalition and the Labor Party would be completely at odds.

As a whole, the coalition finds that public enterprises are in a very favoured position-and Telecom is a typical example-because no competition means less choice. Higher prices are charged due to Public Service conditions and constraints. There is no threat of bankruptcy, so there is no incentive to perform. The only pressure is brought about when people start to talk about competition. That has occurred only in recent years, when some people have taken a particular interest in the performance of these public instrumentalities in relation to the consumer. I therefore hope that those who take an interest in consumer affairs in Australia direct their interest towards consumers rather than the vested interests, which is so frequently evident from the Government today.

It worries and frightens me that we have Liberal members representing the Opposition and any future government in 10 or 15 years, if they are lucky, saying that they will cast aside these protections for those who do not have the same sophisticated capacity in the marketplace. When they buy a product they do not know whether the representations made are correct. So it is too that the small business person who starts a business, goes out on his own, wants the same types of protections.

I find it quite amazing that a person such as the honourable member for Ryan would stand up here and advocate a policy that says, `Do away with these provisions'. What the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) has introduced in the second reading speech, what the Government is doing, is vitally necessary. These are provisions that must be because of the need to maintain the strength of the Trade Practices Act, to ensure that there are no loopholes. As an ex-State member of parliament I, too, would have liked to see the States carry out their responsibilities. That is what it is about. We gave them time to introduce those protections in the food product area, but some did not do it. So what do we do? Stand back and say, `Oh well, it doesn't matter. Let the loopholes prevail. It does not matter that we have this situation where we don't have uniform legislation or nationwide protection. It doesn't matter because we have this fine principle of saying that the States have to do it.'? But what, may I ask, do we do when the States do not do it? That is what this Government is trying to address.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened in Queensland?

—With all due respect to the honourable member for Wannon, Queensland has already been acknowledged for the work it has done in this area. I believe Queensland was the first State to bring down the model food Act. I am not attacking Queensland. Queensland has had some excellent legislative initiatives. I never attack my own State in that area because when it went back to Bill Knox, when he was the Attorney-General and I was the shadow Attorney, we put through initiative and pioneering legislation in all sorts of areas. Vince Lester has done the same thing and Paul Clauson continues to do the same thing. But the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has raised the point and backed the point that I make. It makes no difference if Queensland does it when the other States do not because the Constitution allows another State to manufacture the product and send it into Queensland. It is amazing that an honourable member with some intelligence would say such a thing. Why does he think this Government acted and brought down product safety and protection in the consumer safety areas? Because the States were not acting, because we had a situation where New South Wales would act on an unsafe product, it would ban it and the manufacturers and importers would simply shift it to Victoria. When Victoria acted, banned it and moved to stop the sale, the manufacturers and importers would shift it to South Australia, the Northern Territory or Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members will recall, in my maiden speech in this House at the beginning of 1985 I said that we needed a national approach. Attorney-General Bowen said, `We are going to get that'. It was conservative Ministers such as Vince Lester who said, `We need it', and he acted to do something about it. So that reinforces my argument that it is quite amazing, frightening and alarming when Liberal and National Party members in this chamber want to throw out the good work done not only by this Government but also by conservative State governments.

The provisions being put forward in these amendments are vitally important to keep the strength of the Trade Practices Act. They are vitally important to see that we have a national approach to product safety and they are vitally important to see that we encompass the food area as well. I am quite amazed and surprised that Liberal members would suggest that they are going to move an amendment that will frustrate the endeavours of this Government to ensure that the people of Australia are protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to follow the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). People listening to this debate either in the chamber tonight or on the air waves could be forgiven for thinking that the Opposition intended to vote against the legislation. The honourable member for Capricornia has, in his unusual charismatic and emotive way, given the impression that the Opposition has no interest whatsoever in consumer protection legislation. The reality is that of the three amendments before the House, amendments proposed by the Government, the Opposition intends to support unequivocally two of them and on one amendment, far from opposing it, merely seeks an extension of time.

SPEECH.PARA: To quote the honourable member for Capricornia, he alleged-he kept using this phrase over and over again-that we are guilty of `casting aside all measure of consumer protection'. Nothing could be further from the truth. The history of this Opposition when in government has not been a history of casting aside consumer protection; it has been a history of doing what we are doing tonight and recognising the sovereignty of every consumer.

It is not true to suggest that the Opposition has failed in this House to enter a plea on behalf of every consumer. It is not true to suggest that the Opposition has some form of tunnel vision when it comes to protecting consumers through consumer legislation. It is not true to suggest that we have failed to recognise the rights of consumers across Australia. The plea of the Opposition in the stance it takes on this legislation tonight is a plea to give to every Australian the maximum choice without exposing him or her unduly to the sort of exploitation that would occur in an entirely laissez-faire style of system. What we have asserted is not that the legislation should be thrown out, as the honourable member for Capricornia would have us believe-if that were the case, we would be voting against it-but that the responsibility for consumer affairs is best served in most areas at State level.

The legislation before the House proposes amendments in three areas of the Trade Practices Act. First, it proposes to amend section 53 to prohibit false representation as to the value of goods. As I have said to the House, contrary to the impression given by the honourable member for Capricornia, the Opposition does not oppose that amendment. Secondly, it proposes that section 65u be repealed. In that area we will be moving an amendment proposing that, instead of this section being repealed, the sunset clause be extended for a further two years to allow the States to act in this area of consumer responsibility leaving, once again, accountability and responsibility with the State governments. The final amendment being debated before the House tonight is a proposal to allow officers of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs authorised by the Secretary to the Department-in writing, I might add-to initiate prosecutions in the same way as they are currently instituted by the Trade Practices Commission. The Opposition does not propose to oppose that particular amendment.

Once again, I must take issue with the honourable member for Capricornia who has left both the House and the nation with the impression that the Opposition has no concern at all for consumer affairs protection when, in fact, we propose to support two of the Government amendments and not to vote against the other Government amendment but to move a further amendment that allows greater flexibility for State governments.

The honourable member for Capricornia referred to his maiden speech wherein, once again, in his emotive style he called on the Government to introduce a department of consumer affairs and a Minister for consumer affairs. He will be flattered to know that I was interested enough in his maiden speech to chase through some of the speeches he has given more recently in the House. I discovered that consistent-I commend him on that-with the call he made tonight, he did, on 6 October last year, when addressing the Appropriation Bill, refer, once again, to consumer affairs. He said:
. . . We need to understand companies do not recognise State boundaries.
He said that again tonight. He continued:
They want some uniformity when it comes to advertising laws, labelling laws, packaging laws, health standards, safety requirements and warranties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree?
—My fellow member should give me an opportunity to finish my sentence before he endeavours foolishly to carve me apart. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: That can best be done at a federal level.

I say to the honourable member for Capricornia that that is the point at which the Opposition takes issue with the Government. It takes issue with the statement that this can best be done at the Federal level. We do not contend that it cannot be done at the Federal level or, as he would allege, that if it cannot be done at the Federal level it should not be done at all. We say that there are better ways of doing this than to bring the heavy hand of the Federal Government unnecessarily into the area of consumer affairs. It cannot best be done at the Federal level by the standards applied by the Opposition. We accept that it may be most efficiently, if you like, done at the Federal level, just as a sledgehammer may be easily the most efficient way of cracking nuts-provided that a person does not want any nuts left to eat after he has done the cracking. We contend that the best way to do this is to allow the consumer the maximum choice and the maximum freedom. This gives to the consumer a measure of dignity and sovereignty over consumer rights that should be paramount in any legislative assembly.

We reject the arrogance time and again from the Government benches that suggests that supreme wisdom has somehow been vested in this chamber. There is precious little evidence to back up that claim. Because there is so little evidence to back it up we put it to the Government that there is also wisdom, sovereignty and dignity in the way in which State chambers go about their business. All that we are doing is asserting the federalist policy of the Opposition-recognising the role and accountability of State parliaments-and stating the absolutely irrefutable fact that the State Parliament happens to be closer to the people than does the Federal Parliament.

For the benefit of honourable members opposite, let me say that we are not proud of the delays that have occurred in the implementation of consumer protection. We are not even defensive of those delays. We as a Federal parliament have no right to be dictatorial about those things that are the responsibility of State governments. While those opposite will rush to point out what have been the shortcomings of State governments, I remind them that State governments remain answerable and accountable, as we are, to the consumer-who is, of course, the elector-only more so because they are that much closer to the elector than we are geographically able to be. For that reason, we do not oppose the legislation that is before the House tonight. We seek this amendment in relation to section 65u to give State governments an additional period of two years to play the game, as it were. One of the safeguards that consumers around Australia must recognise is that, whether they are dealing with State or Federal parliaments, the people who represent those seats are answerable to those consumers at State elections. The other safeguard that consumers have in Australia is, surely, the safeguard of a free Press. We as an Opposition want to ensure that the laws of slander do not prevent people who have been disadvantaged by unscrupulous consumer affairs from saying so and ensuring that other consumers are alerted through the free Press to inferior products, beverages or food.

I remind the House, because it seems timely to do so, that the Government has made a great deal of political mileage out of the actions of the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and his price watch committee, which has been set up solely for the purpose of consumer protection. I am quite prepared to accept that the motive for setting up that committee may have been consumer interest, but during the last two weeks we have discovered that some consumers have been disadvantaged by that committee because the privacy that consumers are entitled to has been exposed and lost under its relentless eye and because of the rather wishy-washy way in which the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has gone about supervising his Department. I repeat that the Opposition does not pretend for a moment that existing consumer affairs laws are perfect. We merely contend that to give this sort of power at this time to the Federal Government is to impose a legislative dinosaur on the consumers of Australia.

I repeat that the Opposition does not want to have those vulnerable consumers exploited by ruthless companies. Our whole track record illustrates that point. We are not opposing this legislation for that very reason, but in the interests of the sovereignty of consumers and State governments we are proposing an amendment which gives an additional two years for State governments to come into line. The honourable member for Capricornia shakes his head, as I might have guessed he would. I remind him that consumer affairs protection is in no way vested in the Federal Parliament or even exclusively in the State parliaments. Local government has a key role to play in the protection of consumer affairs and acting in the consumer interest. There would be no member of Federal Parliament who does not have local governing bodies in his constituency already responsible for minimum health standards in such businesses as butchers' shops, restaurants and various food outlets. Consumer affairs protection is not exclusively the right of the Federal Parliament. It is a responsibility shared also by State and local governments. In the interests of the sovereignty of every Australian, the Opposition proposes-not, as the honourable member for Capricornia has alleged, to oppose this legislation-to support those parts which we can and to ensure that State governments maintain their sovereignty in the interests of the consumers of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful for the contribution of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) because he certainly clarified for the House in a very unambiguous way precisely where the Opposition stands in relation to consumer protection law. If I understood the honourable gentleman correctly, he was saying that the Opposition is concerned about consumer protection and the interests of consumers, but that the Opposition believes primarily that this issue is a matter for the States.
—For the consumers.
—For the consumers and indeed for State government regulation rather than Commonwealth government regulation.
—For the consumers, as voters exercising their right to vote.

—The honourable gentleman confirms the assessment I have made. I want to take him and the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), through a little history in order that people may understand the consistency the Opposition has displayed in this area, since consumer protection legislation was first introduced into this Parliament. There are three amendments in the legislation before the House tonight, each of which I will deal with. The Opposition is prepared to support two of them; the other it is not. In relation to the Government's amendment to give the Commonwealth Government a continuing role in consumer protection with regard to food and beverages Australia-wide, the Opposition says we should have only a transient interest in this area and that we ought to leave it to the States to regulate. As I have said, that has been the consistent approach of the Opposition ever since consumer protection laws were debated in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Trade Practices Bill was before the House in 1974, the then shadow Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, a former member for Wentworth, referred to the State laws then in operation and moved for the deletion of the entire consumer protection sections of the Trade Practices Bill. During the next decade the Opposition philosophy went through a maturing process, but unfortunately it was left in exactly the same ideological position as it was in in 1974.

In 1985 when this Government introduced amendments to the Trade Practices Act to confer a power of compulsory recall of dangerous and life-threatening products, the Opposition again opposed the amendments. I remind the House of the types of products we are talking about when we speak of compulsory recall. We are not talking about products that may have some minor deficiency in their construction; we are talking about life-threatening products. If people around Australia listen, they will remember that over recent years there have been examples of swimming pool filters which have literally, in the most horrific manner, disembowelled young children. Those products, of course, were still on the market and still being sold. Only because of the power of compulsory recall can we ensure that such a situation never occurs again. However, in 1985 the Opposition opposed the principle of compulsory recall. We now find the shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs, the honourable member for Ryan-in one of his few Press statements-once more saying that consumers want no more intervention to protect their interests. Of course, that is a consistent view which the Opposition has displayed since 1974.

I turn now to deal very specifically with this issue of States rights. Let us just examine the public record to see the commitment and the reforming zeal which State governments bring to consumer protection law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or lack thereof.

—As the honourable member for Capricornia invites me to do, let me refer to a particular example of the lack of any real commitment on the part of a State government to protect the interests of consumers. I refer you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and honourable members to an episode of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program The Investigators broadcast on 4 September 1985. During the program considerable criticism was made by independent commentators of the appalling nature of consumer protection legislation, some of which literally dates back to the earlier part of this century. On the program the then Tasmanian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Lyons, who was charged with the administration of consumer affairs in that State, in one sentence struck a devastating blow to the Opposition in this Parliament and all those who trumpet the phoney States rights argument in relation to the health and well-being of Australian consumers. Mr Lyons was asked whether Tasmania would have effective consumer protection legislation, and was invited to comment on Australia-wide comparisons. When asked about comparative legislation, this social reformer Tasmanian style, in whom the honourable member for Wakefield and the honourable member for Ryan would have us place our trust as the protector and guardian of consumer rights in Tasmania, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Look, I'm sorry, I'm really not familiar with what it's like on the mainland.

I know that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who sits near me in Parliament, has come into this place with a mission. He has many causes which he will take up during his time in this Parliament. One of those causes is to try to drag the State of Tasmania kicking and screaming into the 1980s when it comes to consumer protection legislation. That has not happened in Tasmania and I regret to say that, despite some efforts by a number of States, the lesson is that the States have not been willing to initiate consistent and uniform reforms. That is why in 1974 the Whitlam Government introduced, for the first time in the history of Australia, the Trade Practices Act and consumer protection provisions. That is why this Government is continuing with legislative reform in the Bill before the House.

Let me address the rhetoric of the Opposition on consumer protection. The honourable member for Ryan and the honourable member for Wakefield in their addresses to the House spoke about consumer sovereignty. They spoke about the role of the market and advanced the view that, by those mechanisms, the interests of consumers would be protected. Let me inform those honourable members that if one entered any law school in Australia or in any democratic country throughout the world, and sought to advance the argument that the interests of consumers are protected by the marketplace, one would fail and be bounced out of the institution. It is not only an economic insult; it is an absolute affront to the intelligence of people to suggest that Mr and Mrs Smith or Mr and Mrs Bloggs or Mr and Mrs Jones in the suburbs of Australia can enter into a contract with any of the major departmental stores, or any of the multinational product manufacturers, and hope to bargain or contract as an equal. But I warn people to beware of the rhetoric, beware of the sleight of hand approach of the Opposition that says, `Consumer sovereignty-let the market operate. Let us deregulate. Let us take all these unnecessary regulations that protect consumers, and let the forces of the market operate and all will be well'.

As I have said, that is simply not in accordance with the reality of how society works. I would have hoped that by 1988 a bipartisan approach would be adopted to issues of consumer protection. Before I turn to the particular provisions of the Bill, I make these points because it is often said that there are no significant differences between the Opposition and the Government on a range of social policies. Let me tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there are cavernous differences on almost every significant social policy. Nowhere is that more evident than in this area of consumer protection where the Opposition advocates a hands-off approach by the Commonwealth.

Three amendments to the Trade Practices Act are before the House tonight. The first provides that a corporation, and in some cases an individual, shall not, in trade or commerce, falsely represent that goods or services are of a particular value. The purpose of the amendment is to clarify the scope of the prohibitions contained in section 53 (a) and section 53 (aa) of the Act, and follows on from the comment in a judgment of the Federal Court of Australia that a representation as to value may be a representation as to quality, as defined in section 53, but whether it does depends on the facts of each case. The purpose of the amendment is to remove any doubt that section 53 prohibits false representations as to the value of goods or services. It is a technical amendment, but it is precisely the sort of technical amendment that has to be made on a regular basis to keep pace with the decisions of the courts and their interpretation of the Trade Practices Act. If these necessary amendments are not made, unscrupulous retailers are able to violate the spirit of the law and have cases against them for what may well be a fraud thrown out of court. So, the amendment is technical but nevertheless important.

Another amendment is administrative, resulting from a transfer of responsibility for the enforcement of part V, division 1a of the Act from the Trade Practices Commission to the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs. Again, it is a technical amendment. I welcome at least the fact that the Opposition has not sought to oppose this amendment.

It is the third amendment which causes the difficulty. Section 65u of the Act was inserted at the behest of the Australian Democrats and of the Opposition and came into force on 1 July 1986. It provides that two years after the day on which the division comes into operation it shall cease to have effect in respect of goods which are food or drinks intended for human consumption. If this section is not repealed it will have the effect of removing foods and beverages from the product safety provisions in the Act.

It was hoped, as has been said in this debate, that there would have been uniform food recall legislation at State level. But that has not happened. Some States do not have specific food recall powers and the existing State powers are not uniform. What an absurd situation it would be if the Government were not moving, as it is, to repeal this section. We would have the crazy result that dangerous products such as the one I referred to-one of many-the swimming pool filter that could disembowel a child, which has happened, tragically, would still be covered by the existing law. If we were not seeking to effect this reform, food and beverages would be outside the ambit of the Act. That would be an absolute farce for the reasons honourable members will quickly see. If we do not repeal the section, the Commonwealth will lose the power to ban the supply of unsafe food and beverages, to set safety or information standards in respect of food and beverages, and to require suppliers to take action to protect consumers from a hazardous food or beverage if voluntary action proved unsatisfactory. The present mandatory notification of voluntary recall of foods and beverages would also be removed.

I had hoped that the Opposition would have acknowledged that food and beverages are essential consumer items. It is simply not feasible to omit food and beverages from the reach of the Act, particularly in relation to recall, in the absence of some other mechanism. I do not want to chronicle the quite substantial history of, literally, life-threatening products, food and beverages, which have been put on sale in shops throughout Australia and which, thankfully, have been recalled in time to avert a major consumer tragedy. It follows, obviously, that we need to have that back-up power to ensure that dangerous products, which may have been contaminated or which may be life-threatening, are able to be recalled.

For the Opposition's benefit, the reason why we need continuing Commonwealth intervention in this area is that food and beverage markets, as the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) said, are not State markets. We are a national market. Food and beverages are distributed and marketed nationally. Therefore, a nationally coordinated approach to safety-related food recalls is essential. State borders are obviously artificial in the national food market. The mandatory notification system for voluntary food recalls has been operating efficiently and effectively. The Opposition has not sought to challenge the operation of the regime since it was put in place over a year and a half ago. In consultation with the States it has recently been agreed that a uniform food legislation and interpretation committee will be established, comprising representatives of the Commonwealth and State health departments. The Commonwealth will provide the chair and the secretariat. It is proposed that the coordination of the national recall system will, in future, be performed by the secretariat and oversighted by that committee. The efficiency and effectiveness of the national food and beverage recall system is heavily dependent on the existing product recall provisions in the Trade Practices Act.

For all those reasons, I would have thought that the Opposition would have abandoned its free market, New Rightist, States rights approach that the Commonwealth has no role in the important area of consumer protection. But I acknowledge that Opposition members are consistent. They said it in 1974, they said it in 1985 and they continue to say it in 1988. They take the same view about environmental protection. They say that it is a State responsibility. We say that there are some vital areas where the States fail to perform their responsibilities and that, therefore, there is a national need for intervention.

I conclude by placing our commitment to consumer protection in the context of the social justice strategy of the Australian Labor Party. That social justice strategy is the guiding light for what we are on about as a national Labor Government in our third term of office. We have the objectives of creating fairness in access to economic power and resources. We have a commitment to protect and ensure the effective exercise of industrial and political rights. We have a commitment to ensure greater equality of access to essential goods and services. Finally, we have a commitment to ensure expanded opportunities for participation by people in decisions affecting their lives. That, I admit, is a grand plan, but all that we do in all the portfolios of this Government is directed towards that grand plan. It is truly our light on the hill as a Federal Labor Government as we proceed through our historic third term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

I would like also to take up just a couple of points with the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). What he was saying was highly emotional and extremely misleading and when he admits that some of the States have already passed laws in this area he contradicts a lot of what he was saying. He relied very heavily on emotion and rhetoric and brought in all sorts of spurious arguments on matters that should have been treated far more seriously than he appeared to be willing to do.

I would like to follow up on a point made by the honourable member for Ryan. It involves consumer groups and in particular the magazine Choice. Some time ago I had occasion to take Choice to task over its involvement in things which I thought were quite beyond the scope of consumer protection, and I still believe this. At the end of 1982 or in early 1983 Choice took it upon itself to write a feature article on gun laws. I found it amazing that an organisation that was supposed to be involved in consumer protection should buy into an issue quite unrelated to what would normally be considered within its ambit of responsibility. I wrote to Choice and took it to task on this. Unfortunately, by the time I got around to writing it was just after I had been elected and all I got back was a reply that my views were political. Maybe they are political but I would suggest that the views of Choice on this occasion were equally political. I wonder whether consumer protection is having its cause advanced by people who quite clearly take strongly political views in areas that should be beyond the ambit of consumer protection.

I also endorse the words of the honourable member for Ryan when he said that in many cases those who represent consumer affairs are strongly anti-business, are often looking for sensational headlines to promote their cause and in many cases present a very unbalanced argument. Even when we do, it certainly does not receive the prominence that the original criticism received.
