I support the amendment that has been foreshadowed by the honourable member for Ryan to extend for a further two years the sunset clause on section 65U. I believe the Government could and should continue to impress upon the State governments that have not done so already the need to consider what they should be doing in this area of protection for consumers, particularly with beverages and food products. Despite what honourable members opposite are saying, I believe there is a very important and clear role for State governments to play in this area. The Government should exercise a little more patience in this area because there is a strong likelihood that State governments, if they feel the need, will take up the opportunity to maintain their rights. It is important in all these things that we maintain some balance between Commonwealth and State responsibilities. Two States have already passed legislation in this area and have been praised by Government members for doing so. This is a very clear indication that the States can and should be allowed to accept responsibility in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Act 1974 has undergone a substantial number of reviews and amendments. For example, the Trade Practices Committee of Review looked at it in 1976. In February 1984, following an internal review, the Hawke Government published a Green Paper canvassing wholesale changes to the Act. In September 1987 the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) announced that the Australian Law Reform Commission was to carry out a review of laws covering product liability. Last month it was announced that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is to undertake a major inquiry into the mergers, acquisitions and monopolies provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Trade Practices Act seeks to regulate various business practices with the principal aim of enhancing and protecting the rights of consumers. This objective is to be realised by the promotion of competition through the outlawing of various collusive and monopolistic practices, principally by part IV of the Act, and by directly strengthening the market position of consumers relative to producers and distributors by prohibiting a variety of unfair practices and creating certain non-excludable rights, principally by part V of the Act.

The philosophy which underpins the Trade Practices Act is that regulation can make markets more efficient, as well as fairer, by doing away with self-serving forms of private regulation and control and by ensuring that consumer choices are based on adequate and accurate information as to price, description and quality. Despite frequent industry calls for greater reliance on self-regulation, the available evidence suggests that parts of the business community cannot be left to their own devices. The Trade Practices Commission, in its 1986-87 annual report, states that it received over 34,000 inquiries and complaints regarding consumer rights under part V of the Act. Likewise, State government agencies are well patronised. For example, the New South Wales Department of Consumer Affairs receives over 200,000 inquiries and in excess of 20,000 formal complaints from consumers each year. Thus critics who argue that such legislation does not fulfil some basic need within the community are flying in the face of the facts.

The object of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill is to make three amendments to the consumer protection provisions in part V of the Act. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill succinctly outlines all the amendments contained in this Bill. I quote:

The first amendment proposes the inclusion in section 53 of an express prohibition on false representations as to the value of goods or services. This is essentially a clarification of the existing prohibition on false representations that goods or services are of a particular standard, quality or grade.

The second amendment proposes the repeal of section 65u. That section would have the effect as from 1 July 1988 of exempting food and drink for human consumption from the product safety and production information provisions in Part V, Division 1a of the Act. The section was enacted in the belief that uniform State/Territory legislation would be enacted to fill the gap, but this has not occurred.

The final amendment proposes that a person authorised by the Secretary to the relevant Commonwealth Department may institute criminal prosecutions without being required to first obtain the consent in writing of the Minister. The amendment is administrative in nature, resulting from the transfer of some functions related to the enforcement of the Act from the Trade Practices Commission to the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs . . .

The three proposed amendments break no new ground. They are consistent with the underlying objectives of the Act and they are not inconsistent with the existing regulatory framework set up by the legislation.

I will now discuss the amendments contained in the Bill. First I refer to clause 3, which deals with false and misleading representations. Section 53 of the Trade Practices Act prohibits various types of false or misleading representations. The section, by way of contrast to more general sections in the Act, actually lists specific areas in which representations need to be accurate and conduct that must not mislead. An infringement of section 53 is a criminal offence. Accordingly, the offence must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt. However, it has been held that mens rea is not an element. This means that wrongful intention is not relevant to a person's guilt or innocence under the section.

In 1977 the Fraser Government inserted sections 53 (a) and 53 (aa) into the Act. Those sections presently cover false representations going to the particular standard, quality, grade, composition, style or model, particular history or particular previous use of goods. Following the decision in Ducret v. Chaudhary's Oriental Carpet Palace Pty Ltd it is unclear as to whether the sections as they are currently worded include false representation as to value. The purpose of the proposed amendment is to apply the full provisions of the Act to ensure that false representation as to value of goods is prohibited.

The facts of Ducret v. Chaudhary's Oriental Carpet Palace Pty Ltd were that a businessman, Chaudhary, was charged under section 79 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 with being knowingly concerned with the commission of an offence against the Act by the company. The prosecutor alleged that in contravention of section 53e of the Trade Practices Act the company, that is Chaudhary's Oriental Carpet Palace Pty Ltd, had made misleading statements in a Melbourne newspaper with respect to the price of certain carpets. One of the allegedly offending statements was that the price of one type of carpet was `usually $4,675; sale price $1,759; now only $497'. In another part of the advertisement, an illustration of another type of carpet was accompanied by a drawing of a price ticket which bore the legend `usually $250; sale price $125; now only $12.50'. The prosecutor alleged that the statements were misleading because they indicated that the usual or fair retail prices of the carpets in Melbourne were $4,675 and $250, which allegedly was not the case. Expert evidence was adduced that it was impossible to specify a single specific price as the usual retail price in Melbourne of rugs of a particular size and type.

The court dismissed the charges against the company on the basis that the actual advertisement in this case did not in its view contain a statement which indicated either the usual retail price or a fair retail price or a fair retail value of a rug to which the advertisement referred. The court, however, allowed for the possibility that in some circumstances goods which had a definite degree of some reasonable characteristic which was recognised or so widely accepted within the relevant trade or by commercial practice generally that to ascribe that value to them in, say, an advertisement was inferentially to warrant that they were of standard liked to that value.

I now refer to clause 4, which deals with the repeal of section 65u. The section in question forms part of division 1a of part V of the Act. That division, inserted in the Act in 1986, provides for the banning of unsafe goods, the declaration of product safety and product information and the mandatory recall of hazardous goods. The new division replaced the former section 62 and 63 of the Act, which dealt with the area of the law in a less detailed fashion. Prior to their repeal, sections 62 and 63 provided for the creation of consumer product safety standards and consumer product information standards by regulation. Such regulations were made by the Governor-General in pursuance of his power under section 172 of the Act. The Minister could also declare that a particular standard, or part of it, prepared by the Standards Association of Australia, or another association or body, was a standard for the purposes of sections 62 or 63. Section 62 (2d) permitted the banning of goods considered to be `unsafe'.

In introducing the 1986 amendments to the Act, the Attorney-General stated the Government's reasoning for replacing sections 62 and 63 with a new code. Those reasons were that, first, the old provisions had no application to unsafe products supplied before a banning order is issued; secondly, there were no powers available to deal with the problem of unsafe products which had reached the hands of consumers; and, thirdly, under the legislation adequate opportunity was not provided to review decisions taken by the Minister under sections 62 and 63.

Section 65b provides for the publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of various warning notices by the Minister in relation to potentially injurious goods. Consumer product safety standards, unsafe goods declarations, and banning orders are dealt with in section 65c. Consumer product information standards are outlined in section 65d. In addition to the formulation of new standards, existing safety and information standards may be adopted and declared by the Minister, and this course is outlined in section 65e. The new area of compulsory product recall is dealt with in section 65f, and section 65g covers compliance with such orders. A deeming provision in section 65h is concerned with loss or damage suffered as a result of non-compliance with a compulsory recall order. Conferences may be held before the finalisation of certain decisions and the provisions dealing with these conferences are contained in sections 65j and 65q. Conferences may also be held following the declaration that goods are unsafe, and that is dealt with in section 65m.

It is now compulsory to notify the Trade Practices Commission where goods are voluntarily recalled because of potential danger and this duty, in addition to penalties for their breach, is outlined in section 65r. Section 65t safeguards insurance contracts in situations where information is supplied to authorities in respect of defective goods. Section 65u provides for the cessation of the operation of the division in respect of food and drink intended for human consumption after a period of two years. To assist suppliers regarding the operation of the new product safety provisions, the Commonwealth Office of Consumer Affairs has issued a publication entitled Product Safety-Guide to the Operation of the Trade Practices Act. It is section 65u which is the subject of the second of the three proposed amendments to the Act. It provides:

At the expiration of 2 years after the day on which this Division comes into operation, this Division shall cease to have effect in respect of goods which are foods and drinks intended for human consumption.
The explanatory memorandum states:
The Section 65u was inserted by the Trade Practices Revision Act 1986 as a result of an amendment in the Senate.
The amendment was proposed by Senator Haines, Leader of the Australian Democrats. In moving the amendment she said:
The purpose of the sunset clause was to chivvy the States into getting their food Acts into line.

The Democrat amendment was supported by the Liberal and National parties and consequently became law. Two years have now passed since the sunset clause was inserted in division 1a. If this legislation is not passed division 1a of part V of the Act will not apply to food and drink. The Democrat amendment gave rise to a number of separate issues. First, there is some uncertainty as to whether its authors intended the amendment to apply to all of division 1a or just to the recall powers principally contained in sections 65f and 65j. In so far as recall powers are concerned, only Western Australia has during the past two years enacted new regulations providing for recall of unsafe products. Queensland had earlier enacted regulations providing for product recall, and South Australia claims that its Food Act 1985 provides sufficient power to cover its problems in this area. A third issue is whether it is appropriate for food and drink to be treated as separate categories. In 1976 the Trade Practices Committee of Review considered:

That at the present time food should not be excluded from the products in respect of which a standard may be prescribed under the Trade Practices Act . . . when national uniform food standard legislation is adopted in Australia the Committee would see it as appropriate for that legislation to prescribe standards for food products rather than under the Trade Practices Act.

As yet no such uniform national law exists. A model food Act was drafted by a working party of Federal and State health Ministers in 1980. It has been adopted in principle by all States but the legislation that has resulted to date has not been uniform. New South Wales, for example, has yet to enact legislation that would include the model food Act in its Pure Food Act 1908. The Australian Capital Territory does not have a food ordinance. Similarly, the food standards code recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council, which was gazetted by the Federal Government on 27 August 1987, has yet to achieve uniform coverage.

On the question of recalls, the 1976 Trade Practices Committee of Review found that the inability of the Trade Practices Act to deal with hazardous products was `a substantial legislative defect'. Indeed, one justification for consumer protection law is that consumers are seldom in a position to evaluate the worth or safety of a product until that product has been purchased or consumed. Consumers may not realise that a product is unsafe or unmerchantable until it is too late for them to do anything about it. In the case of food and drink, this precept applies with added force. In the absence of any separate or distinct uniform code governing the sale of food and drink, it is absolutely necessary to continue applying the provisions of the Trade Practices Act to those products.

Arising out of this latter debate is the question of States rights, which was raised earlier. The position of the so-called States righters is rather weak. Section 65u gave the States two years to enact the necessary recall laws. Only one State, Western Australia, has enacted such legislation. Furthermore, the Federal law acts only as a reserve power; that is, mandatory sanctions are to be applied only if voluntary compliance is not forthcoming. In addition the Commonwealth, following the High Court of Australia decision in the concrete pipes case, has clear power under the Federal compact to enact such legislation.

Furthermore, the legislation will not inhibit the ability of the States to pass laws dealing with the supply of food and drink. The States have not, through the Uniform Food Law Interpretation Committee, objected to the removal of section 65u. Recall powers preventing re-export from State to State are more expeditiously managed by the Commonwealth, and this power is no different from the Commonwealth power under the Customs Act to prevent the import into Australia of dangerous goods for sale. Even if the States succeeded in passing uniform food legislation it is doubtful whether such legislation would remain uniform for long.

These three amendments make up hallmark legislation to enhance and strengthen the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. It is a positive piece of legislation and the amendment proposed by the Opposition has in it all the faults contained in the original amendment put forward by Senator Haines during the debate in the Senate in April 1986.

In Victoria, the readjustment taking place under the new formula will be completed in four years, rather than seven years, as is the case in some other States. This implies some quite catastrophic reductions in the Commonwealth funds available to some local councils. The implication of the Victorian Grants Commission formula is that Federal funds will be applied across the board, based on the ability of all municipalities throughout Victoria to raise revenue. Previously, the formula was based on the average revenue raising capacity of the top 25 per cent of municipalities. The new formula takes into account the average revenue of all municipalities, which is 9.3c in the dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the new system, those shires and councils which are asset rich but revenue poor will be discriminated against in a most unfair manner. Urban based councils have a greater capacity to extract revenue from ratepayers whose disposable income is mostly derived from employment in the metropolitan area. In rural Victoria, councils have to strike a rate which is relative to the income producing capacity of the land. In terms of raising rate revenue this is often very difficult. Those councils which have been careful in their loan borrowings for capital works, and therefore have a lower interest bill, again will be discriminated against, as their interest bill will tend to be less than the average borrowings of councils throughout Victoria. Similarly, those councils which have not undertaken major welfare initiatives, will not meet the formula requirements.

At a time when governments throughout Australia are being encouraged to reduce expenditure, the thrust of the Victorian Grants Commission formula is to encourage increased expenditure at the local level to attract Federal moneys. Not only are local councils being encouraged to spend more but also they are being compared with neighbouring councils in their ability to attract Federal funds and retain similar rates.

The Victorian Government has been imposing further burdens on local government since 1982. In the beginning, an offer is made on a dollar for dollar basis. This means that the local government provides a service which was formerly provided by the State government. This is particularly so in the welfare-recreational area. Further down the track, the State Government withdraws its State funding support and local government is left funding the activity from local rates. The Cain Government's bid to amalgamate councils in Victoria was rejected outright. However, the Cain socialist Government is intent on achieving its amalgamation objectives by stealth, in that those smaller, efficient, locally representative councils will be starved of funds until they are forced to look at amalgamation alternatives.

In my own electorate of Corangamite, the figures give a stark contrast between those urban based councils which have had virtually no change in their Commonwealth funding-both in real and monetary terms-and rural based municipalities. For instance, the Winchelsea Shire will receive a reduction of 9.06 per cent in 1987-88, and by 1990-91 its grant will be reduced by 72 per cent. In 1986-87, the Winchelsea Shire received $448,667 and by 1990-91 this will fall to $123,000. The Shire of Otway will suffer a 44 per cent reduction in Federal funding over a similar period. The Leigh Shire, well known for its conservative approach to expenditure, will suffer a loss of funding from $161,318 in 1986-87 to $26,000 in 1990-91, a reduction of 83 per cent. In the Leigh Shire there is a considerable contribution to welfare services from volunteers. This contribution is not recognised on the balance sheets, and again does not assist the Grants Commission formula for Federal funding. In fact, in this instance, the Leigh Shire is being positively discriminated against for showing initiative in providing volunteer services. It would appear that, under the new formula, larger regionally based councils will not be affected and could gain extra revenue from the Commonwealth. For instance, the city of Colac received $524,285 in 1986-87 and by 1990-91 will receive $816,000-an increase of 55 per cent.

I call on the Government in the name of fairness and equity to instigate an immediate and urgent reassessment of the presumably `unintended consequences' of the Victorian Grants Commission formula, administered under the direction of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to bring to the attention of the House a matter of major concern to me as the member for Wakefield. It is a matter of concern that is shared by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), who is currently on the Opposition front bench.
—Is it only temporary?

—I wish it were. This issue is a matter that demands the attention of the House because it concerns the way in which hospital facilities are being delivered to those constituents who reside in South Australian country electorates, particularly the electorates of Wakefield and Barker. Incredibly, the South Australian Health Commission has the audacity to propose the closure of three major country health facilities in South Australia. Two of these facilities are located in my electorate, at Laura and Blyth, and the third is in the electorate of the honourable member for Barker and is located at Tailem Bend. So widespread is the indignation of South Australian country people at the proposal of the South Australian Health Commission to close these facilities that only last month the Country Women's Association (CWA) marched on the South Australian Parliament House and presented a petition containing 40,000 signatures opposing the closure of country hospitals, as proposed by the South Australian Health Minister, John Cornwall. The signatures were collected in 23 towns, while simultaneously CWA members pushed a bed from Cummins on the far west coast of South Australia to the city as a protest measure against Dr Cornwall's rationalisation bid.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Cornwall defends the decision to close these hospitals on the grounds that such a move would be `significant in terms of reducing the number of assets requiring replacement in the long term'. I put it to you, Madam Speaker, that it is relatively insignificant in terms of the total expenditure on the Medicare budget. It is the blow-out in the Medicare budget and the consequent reduction in funds in the Medicare reservoir that has put pressure on the South Australian Health Commission. Consider, for example, the fact that the current Medicare levy of 1.25 per cent raises about $2,065m. The cost of Federal hospital and medical services, if I may take a further point, is $5,212m. To meet this total cost, a levy of 3.15 per cent would be required. The total cost of health care in Australia-Federal, State and local government-is $18,000m, equivalent to $25 a week for every man, woman and child in Australia, or $100 per family per week. This figure should be compared with the $5 or $6 Medicare levy we are paying each week, thinking that we are meeting the total cost of our health schedule program.

It is clearly the blow-out in Medicare expenditure which is soaking up Commonwealth funds and denying to Dr Cornwall and the Health Commission the opportunity to continue the services that South Australians have come to take for granted. I point out that in my electorate, in the towns of Laura and Blyth, these hospitals are the focal point of the towns. The current proposal of the South Australian Health Commission, which is contained in a government discussion paper, is that hospitals with 20 or 30 beds should, if you please, be converted to old folks homes. The suggestion, of course, is that there would be old folks home facilities and, adjacent to these facilities, there would be four or five acute care beds available from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. I ask you, Madam Speaker, what does a person do if he lives in Laura, Blyth or Tailem Bend and becomes ill at some time other than during the convenient hours of 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.?

I return to my earlier point. These hospitals are the focal point of the rural communities. What Dr Cornwall fails to recognise, and what the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) fails to recognise, is that the cost of caring for people in these country hospitals is only half the cost of equivalent care in a major urban institution. So much of what is done in these country hospitals is done on a voluntary basis. The present action being taken by Dr Cornwall will destroy the very heart of these rural communities by destroying that focus for voluntary activity that has characterised these rural communities, with which members on this side of the House so readily identify.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to refer to something that is very much part of the Parliament and goes back many centuries.
—The Speaker's chair?

—No, it is not the Speaker's chair. It is not something so materialistic as that to which the honourable member refers; in fact, it is the right of citizens to petition Parliament. The right of petitioning Parliament remains a fundamental right of citizens. I shall rely on Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice, pages 688 and 689, for the matters I want to raise tonight. The right of petitioning the Crown and parliament for redress of grievances dates back to the reign of King Edward I in the thirteenth century. It was from petitions that legislation by Bill was gradually derived. Petitions have been described as the oldest of all parliamentary forms-the fertile seed of all the proceedings of the House of Commons. The form and purpose of petitions has changed over the centuries, the present form having developed in the seventeenth century. The rights of petitioners and the power of the House of Commons to deal with petitions were affirmed by the following resolution in 1669:

SPEECH.PARA: That it is an inherent right of every Commoner of England to prepare and present petitions to the House in case of grievance; and of the House of Commons to receive them. That it is the undoubted right and privilege of the House of Commons to adjudge and determine, touching the nature and matter of such Petitions, how far they are fit and unfit to be received.

I repeat: the right of petitioning Parliament remains a fundamental right of the citizens. My reason for raising this matter is that in the recent changes to the Standing Orders, petitions are now received only once a week. It is true that the matter was before the House and that was the agreement that was reached. I think, on reflection, that there would have been much more debate on the issue had honourable members on both sides been aware of what was about to happen. In the past it has not been difficult for the powers-that-be to determine whether a petition was acceptable to the Parliament.

I accept that there have to be certain rules, but my complaint is that in the changes to the petitioning, and bearing in mind that petitioning of Parliament is so terribly important, one fact that has been overlooked is that many petitions in the community do not comply with the letter of the new requirements. I have 10,000 signatures from petitioners on a very important issue, that is, the question of the possible introduction of food irradiation in Australia. I feel that the petition should be not only a right of the citizen but also a part of the democratic process. Through petitions, the individual citizen feels that he has access to this Parliament.

I hope that commonsense will prevail and that those petitions that are currently in shopping centres, clubs, on notice boards, in factories and canteens and have been signed by citizens to convey their particular grievance to this Parliament will be received and will not be disqualified because they do not contain a particular word that is necessary. I am sure that members on both sides of the House would agree that there is a need for some leeway, perhaps a moratorium, so that all petitions can be received properly in the House and the new wording that is required hopefully will be available as soon as possible

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk tonight about the unscrupulous activities of some life insurance companies. Because it would be difficult to condense a description of all the unscrupulous activities of all insurance companies into a five-minute speech, I will confine my comments to the activities of the Mutual Life and Citizens Assurance Company Ltd (MLC) and in particular its exploitation of the agents who sell its policies and the consequences of this treatment for the insurance buying public. I was contacted recently by Mr Peter Anderson, a former agent for MLC and one of my constituents, who feels that he and other agents have been cleverly exploited by the insurance company. He explained to me the way in which he and no doubt hundreds of others are enticed into situations of massive indebtedness to the company in a way which would put most used car salesmen to shame. It is certainly not the way in which people expect these supposedly highly reputable companies to behave, probably because of the image they project of themselves through their multimillion dollar advertising campaigns.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Anderson worked as an agent of MLC from March to November 1985, when financial difficulties and a healthy dislike of the work led to his resignation. His original decision to enter the field of selling insurance was encouraged by the company's typical recruitment lines, such as `Be your own boss' and `Earn unlimited income'. The reality was sadly different. The system under which Mr Anderson worked at MLC was the highly reprehensible advance system, whereby the sales agents were advanced an amount of money-in Mr Anderson's case, $200 at that time-and it was up to them to sell policies to cover the advance. If they did not earn enough commission, the money was still owed to the insurance company; in other words, there was no risk to MLC. More often than not agents found themselves getting deeper and deeper into debt with the company. The motive behind the advance system is clear-to force the agents into making sales to cover their debt with the company. When the debt increases, the agents become desperate and tend to do anything to make a sale.

There is no doubt that this sort of pressure was brought to bear on the agent, Anthony Bryant and Co., which was before the court last year on a charge of misconduct in the sale of insurance policies issued by Scottish Amicable Life Assurance Society. In that case it was alleged that the agent told potential buyers that policies with 25-year terms could be cashed in after 10 years. That is the sort of pressure brought to bear on agents who sell for companies such as MLC through the advance system. The company itself is deemed to be completely free of blame when this sort of thing happens.

It is not only through the system of commission advances that companies seek to keep their agents permanently indebted to them. MLC also offers very low interest rates to agents who meet certain qualifications. However, a condition of the loan is immediate refinancing upon termination of employment. Agents who want to get off this never ending treadmill face the prospect of not only paying back advances but also their loans refinanced at considerably higher interest rates. The only option for many agents is to try to sell their way out of debt with the company. That is when desperation sets in and where the potential danger lies for the policy buying public. The temptation exists to be less than honest when making a sale, as in the case of Anthony Bryant.

It is also apparent that MLC and similar companies pumped large numbers of recruits through their system. The apparent motive behind this was that each agent had a minimum number of friends and relatives who would purchase a policy. Once these ran out, the agents sank more and more into debt until they got out of the game, owing money to the company. However, MLC retained the policies and collected the premiums. This is where an even more reprehensible policy of MLC comes into play. After leaving the company and paying their debt, the agents breathe a sigh of relief, thinking they are free. However, at the end of a two-year period from the date of their resignation, they receive a bill from MLC for commission paid to them for all policies sold by them which had subsequently been cancelled. The company makes the agents pay back the commission earned for selling a policy if that policy is subsequently cancelled for whatever reason. That is the case with Mr Anderson. Recently he received a letter from a debt collector saying, `Give us back $1,800 because some of the policies you sold went bad'.

I ask: Where in all this is there any risk whatever for the insurance company? Any advance paid to the agent is either recovered by the commission for a sale or is owed back to the company. In the case of any policies which are cancelled, the agent has to pay back the commission, even if he no longer sells for that company. In the case of the loans, though the interest rates are low, they are still revenue raisers which in any case need to be renegotiated if the agent leaves the company. This is all perfectly legal, but in my view highly immoral and extremely suspect, and structured in such a way as to encourage poor sales practices and possible illegal activity on the part of an agent. When this does occur, the company is at no legal fault despite the direct and undoubted link between the activities and company policy.

According to information obtained from the Office of the Insurance Commissioner, this sort of thing is still going on today. The only change seems to be that the scheme is a little more refined in that the companies have moved from the advance system to one of lending the money to the agents. This slight change does not alter the fact that every day hundreds of insurance policies are sold by agents who are under immense pressure to get themselves out of debt. This situation cannot be in the best interests of the policy buying public, and I urge the Government to legislate to clean up this aspect of the insurance industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 19 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Radiation Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council prepared and published a final draft code of practice for the design and safe operation of non-medical irradiation facilities using sealed gamma sources, bremsstrahlung or electron sources with energies up to 10 million electron-volts.
(2) Did he either authorise or endorse the preparation of the code; if so, (a) when and (b) why.
(3) If he did not authorise or endorse the preparation of the code, who did and under what authority.
(4) Does the draft code cover irradiation facilities for non-medical purposes, including the irradiation of food.
(5) Does the draft code cover irradiators incorporating the radioactive substances cobalt 60 or caesium 137, and will such sources be contained in a storage pool which usually contains water.
(6) Is caesium 137 soluble in water.

(7) Does the draft code state that it is anticipated that future developments in irradiators, including the use of mobile machine sources for the irradiation of food, may require additions to the code; if so, what is the reason for such an inclusion in the draft code and is it a provision being anticipated by 1 or more States.
(8) If it is being anticipated by some States, which States are showing an interest in mobile irradiators.
(9) Has his attention been drawn to a recent accident in Brazil involving caesium 137; if so, is he able to say how many deaths resulted from this accident and how many more deaths are anticipated.
(10) Is he able to say whether the accident resulted in a population of over 70,000 having to be tested for radiation contamination.
(11) Is caesium 137 the same radioactive substance used in some food irradiation plants.
(12) Is caesium 137 a product of the nuclear weapons industry.
(13) What is the half life of caesium 137.
(14) Can an exposure to the whole body, or critical organs, of only a few gray produce acute radiation syndrome with severe illness and possible death.
(15) What is the range of capacity in curie, of irradiators whose source is (a) cobalt 60 and (b) caesium 137.
(16) Is ozone produced in the operation of an irradiation plant using either cobalt 60 or caesium 137; if so, what happens to this ozone and is it harmful to health.

(17) Are some components of machine source irradiators capable of generating radio frequency radiation; if so, what is radio frequency radiation and if it is harmful to health, what is the nature of its effects.

(18) In the service and maintenance of machine source irradiators are there circumstances for personnel to be exposed to additional potential hazards; if so, what are these hazards and how can personnel be protected from them.

(19) Does the potential exist for machine source irradiators to become contaminated from induced radioactivity and can this type of contamination occur in machine sources designed for food irradiation.
(20) What is contamination from induced radioactivity and how long does such contamination last.
(21) Can such contaminated machines be cleaned or is it necessary to dispose of them.
(22) If it is necessary to dispose of contaminated machines, how can this be done.

(23) Would food put through a contaminated machine become radioactive or contaminated; if so, can the contaminated or radioactive food be identified easily and what methods would be used to dispose of it.
(24) Does the draft code have provisions for the retention of medical records of employees who in the course of their employment may be exposed to ionizing radiation; if not, why not.

(25) In cases where either cobalt 60 or caesium 137 is imported, will there be a Government to Government contract covering the import, storage, record keeping and return of spent fuel; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Radiation Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council is preparing a draft ``Code of Practice for the Design and Safe Operation of Non-medical Irradiation Facilities using Sealed Gamma Ray Sources, or X-ray or Electron Sources with Energies up to 10 MeV''.

The Code is approaching but is not yet in final draft form and would only be published by the National Health and Medical Research Council after consideration and approval by the Radiation Health Committee and Public Health Advisory Committee.

(3) Following initial consideration by the Radiation Health Committee and the Food Standards Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council in 1985, the Public Health Advisory Committee agreed to the development of the Code by the Radiation Health Committee.

(4) The draft Code covers irradiation facilities used for non-medical purposes. If the irradiation of food were approved in Australia, the draft Code would be applicable to facilities used for this purpose.

(5) Sealed source irradiators covered by the draft Code are limited to those incorporating the radioactive substances cobalt-60 or caesium-137 where the source is contained in a storage pool (usually containing water) when not in use.
(6) Caesium-137 is generally used in the form of a salt such as caesium chloride which is water soluble. The caesium is suitably enclosed in stainless steel capsules which prevent leakage.

(7) The draft Code in the present form covers fixed irradiation facilities only. In the draft Code it is pointed out that any future developments in irradiator design, such as the use of mobile machine sources for the irradiation of food, which are outside the scope of the present Code, will require appropriate modifications at the time. This applies to any State where such a development might be proposed.
(8) I am unaware of particular interest in mobile irradiators in any State.

(9) The Brazil incident, which occurred in mid-September 1987, has received widespread press publicity. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has advised that by the end of November, 4 people had died and a further 28 are under continuing medical surveillance.
(10) The IAEA has also advised that a total of about 80,000 people living in the area have been checked for contamination.
(11) Yes. Caesium-137 is used in a very few food irradiation plants. Most plants use cobalt-60.

(12) Caesium-137 is formed within a nuclear reactor (whether civilian or military) as a by-product of the fission reaction. The caesium is extracted during refurbishment of the fuel rods of the reactor.
(13) The half life of caesium-137 is 30 years.

(14) Yes, exposure of the human body to an absorbed dose of a few gray in a short time interval (either to the whole body or to critical organs) could cause acute radiation syndrome with severe illness and possible death.

(15) Large quantities of caesium-137 or cobalt-60 (of the order of a million curies) can be required in an irradiation facility. The exact quantity will depend on the design of the plant and the intended use.

(16) Ozone is produced during the operation of irradiation facilities using caesium-137 or cobalt-60, and can be harmful to health in sufficient concentration. Ozone is unstable and reverts to the normal form of oxygen in time. The exposure of personnel to ozone in an irradiation facility can be controlled using suitable ventilation systems and time delay interlocks to prevent access of personnel to areas of potentially high concentration before a preset time has elapsed.

(17) Various components of machine sources can generate electromagnetic radiation at radio frequencies (i.e. radiofrequency radiation). At high exposure levels behavioural effects, genetic effects, effects on development and teratogenic effects have been observed in animals. Cataracts and internal body lesions have also been produced. Studies on humans who have been occupationally exposed to low levels of radiofrequency radiation have yielded inconsistent results. However, recommended maximum exposure levels have been set with a high margin of safety so that any deleterious effects on workers or the general population are extremely unlikely.

(18) The service of the radiation generator in a machine source facility can be expected to generate particular radiation-related hazards. While machine sources are safe when de-energized, it is likely that service personnel will be required to energize the equipment and may need to disarm safety interlocks from time to time. Personnel can be protected from these hazards by suitable engineering design and administrative controls which relate to how personnel use the facility.

(19) Radioactivity can be induced in components of a machine source irradiator which are irradiated by the electron or bremsstrahlung beam, to an extent that depends on the energy, beam power and type of material irradiated. Some degree of activity is probable for energies above about 10 MeV. Levels of induced activity would be extremely small in machine source irradiators designed for food irradiation as these irradiators are limited to a maximum energy of 5 MeV for bremsstrahlung beams and 10MeV for electron beams.
(20) See (19). Any radioactivity induced in components of an irradiator would decay with time at a rate which depends on the type of material irradiated.

(21) Since the components of the irradiator itself become radioactive, cleaning would not be possible. If the level of induced activity was considered to be a problem, such components would be left for a sufficient time for the induced radioactivity to decay, or be disposed of appropriately.
(22) Disposal of complete machines would never be required. At most, small components with low levels of activity would be affected.

Issues raised in questions (17) and (22) are common to machine irradiation facilities used in radiation therapy, where many years of operating experience have indicated that induced activities do not pose intractable problems.

(23) Induced activity in irradiator components would not be transferable to food passing through the irradiator. The food itself may become radioactive at an extremely low level due to the irradiation process. At most this activity would only be a small fraction of the natural radioactivity content of the food.

(24) The draft Code does not require retention of medical records of employees who may be exposed to ionizing radiation in the course of their employment. Such employees are required to be issued with personal monitors to record their exposure to ionizing radiation. Recommended exposure limits have been set to ensure that medical problems due to radiation exposure in workers or the general population are extremely unlikely. State authorities (who licence the operation of the facilities) can direct that medical examinations are performed if this is considered necessary.

(25) Importation of cobalt-60 or caesium-137 will require approval under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. This approval will be conditional upon the importer and the user having appropriate licences under the relevant State Radioactive Substances Act. This licence will require that safe transport conditions, operational procedures and storage conditions are used and that satisfactory arrangements are in place regarding the ultimate return of the sources to the supplier.
